column2: PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16? One of the world's two oldest known nonhuman primates, a 56-year-old female orangutan named Guarina, died this morning at the Philadelphia Zoological Garden.

A 36-year-old Bronx mother shopping with her sister-in-law and 18-month-old daughter was stabbed repeatedly yesterday when she resisted a pursesnatcher who was later saved from an angry crowd by two police officers, the police said.

MONROF, N.C., Jan. 16 (AP) The kidnapping charges from which Robert Williams, a black activist, fled the country 14 years ago were dropped today because the prosecution said its principal witness was too ill to testify.

After sentencing Sara Jane Moore to Life imprisonment for the attempted murder of President Ford, Federal District Judge Samuel Conti told the convicted woman: "You wouldn't be standing before me if we had an effective capital punishment law. The one thing people care about is their skin."

BONN, Jan. 16 A death notice in a small Bavarian paper today announced that Adolf Hitler's mother-in-law,. Franziska Braun, died Tuesday in the St. Adelheid old-age home at Ruhpolding in the Bavarian Alps. She was 90 years old.
BOSTON, Jan. 16 (UPI) Dave Cowens scored on a critical 3-point play with 1 minute 42 seconds left in the game, helping the Boston Celtics to beat the Philadelphia 76ers tonight, 118-110.

Mary Orr, an author as well as an actress, once wrote a story called "The Wisdom of Eve," which Joseph Mankiewicz transformed into the movie classic "All About Eve." Miss Orr's new play, "Grass Widows," which opened Thursday at Stage 73, desperately needs Mr. Mankiewicz but it is not worth his, or anyone's time.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 The Federal Reserve Board reduced the discount rate today from 6 percent to 5 percent, the lowest level since the spring of 1973.

Earnings of the International Business Machines Corporation rose 31.8 per cent in the fourth quarter last year and 8.5 per cent for all of 1975, according to the annual report issued yesterday. Earnings were the highest for any quarter or any year in its history, while foreign revenues exceeded domestic business for the first time.

Dick Hannah, the publicityman who represented Howard Hughes, the billionaire recluse, for nearly two decades, died Thursday evening at his home in Los Angeles. Mr. Hannah, who had undergone open-heart surgery in July, was 60 years old.
NEWARK, Jan. 16 A Federal judge issued an order today temporarily restraining the state from enforcing a monthold law that prohibits the use of Medicaid payments for abortions.

Renata Tebaldi broke off her first New York appearance in two years last night at Carnegie Hall because she was "too emotional" to go on. Sir Rudolf Bing of Columbia Artists, sponsors of Miss Tebaldi's recital told a disappointed but sympathetic crowd that he hoped to reschedule the soprano in 10 days to two weeks.
PRIVAS, France Thousands of Dutch citizens have penetrated the mountains and valleys here in the remote Ardeche District, buying up farms and old stone houses ...
Kate Rothko, 25-year-old daughter of Mark Rothko, the abstract expressionist painter, was appointed sole administrator of her father's $30 million estate yesterday by Surrogate Millard L. Midonick.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 President Ford's campaign organization began today an attempt to link Ronald Reagan with the politically disastrous position on Social Security that Senator Barry Goldwater advocated in the 1964 Presidential contest.

A complete revision in the long distance telephone rate structure of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which could result in lower rates for residential customers and higher costs for business and Government, has been recommended to the Federal Communications Commission by its common carrier bureau.
Kate Rothko, 25-year-old daughter of Mark Rothko, the abstract expressionist painter, was appointed sole administrator of her father's $30 million estate yesterday by Surrogate Millard L. Midonick.

It is to Eartha Kitt's advantage but also to her disadvantage that she has a well-established image. When she comes on in the Persian Room of the Plaza Hotel, she sparks an immediate sense of identity with her remarkably feline face and that voice with the hummingbird notes that whir around in the upper register.

City College has offered a $100 reward for the recovery of a six-inch-high silver cup donated to the college 50 years ago by the class of 1875 and stolen yesterday. A college official said someone had entered Shepard Hall, at 138th Street and Convent Avenue, at 8:45 A.M. and smashed a glass case to get the cup.

RAHWAY, Jan. 16 "Furloughs have kept my wife married to me," Thomas Zuppa said. "My son is 4 and he thinks I'm away at college or something. But my going home gave him faith in me again. But now all that is gone because somebody else screwed up."

KINSHASA, Zaire, Jan. 16 Holden Roberto, president of the National Front for the Liberation of Angola, angrily denied tonight an American assessment that his movement was approaching the point of collapse.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 Officials of the First National City Bank and the Chase Manhattan Bank have declined a request to appear before a House Monetary Affairs subcommittee next week to discuss the circumstances that led to the inclusion of the two banks on a so-called "problem list" kept by the Comptroller of the Currency.

Governor Carey yesterday appointed Justice Leonard H. Sandler of State Supreme Court as the new presiding justice for the special grand juries now hearing evidence brought by Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor, on corruption in the criminal justice system.

TEAM FOR TWO Tom Jones, lyricist, and Harvey Schmidt, composer, creators of the long-running "The Fantasticks," and other musicals, will be the featured guests tomorrow at 8 P.M. in the second program of this season's musicianS' series at the 92d Street Y.M. Y.W.H.A., at Lexington Avenue. Appearing with the partners will be the singers Susan Watson and DicK Latessa. Admission is $6. Reservations: 427-6000, extension 720.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 Industrial production ended on a strong note in 1975, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, amid other signs of recovery in the economy and abating inflation and interest rates.
Right Mind returns from a one-month's rest today to oppose five rivals in the $54,700 Aqueduct Handicap at one mile.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 Eleven years ago, Robert J. Morgado left Hawaii for the American mainland for the first time in his 21 years and arrived at the State University here as a graduate student in public administration.

Executives of a large public relations agency that has been representing the Iranian national airline here expressed puzzlement and surprise yesterday over disclosures that Iran Air had signed a contract with a concern employing Marion Javits, wife of Senator Jacob K. Javits.
Mayor Beame's offer last week to negotiate lower realestate taxes and lower rents on city-owned land with businesses willing to create jobs in New York is another ...

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 16 To the bemusement of a generally indifferent and inattentive viewing public, three of the six Presidential candidates in next week's Democratic caucuses here have turned to television and radio to reach the small number of voters who will determine the contest's outcome.

NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 16 (AP) Landmark Communications Inc., publisher of The Virginian-Pilot and The LedgerStar, has became the first Virginia publisher convicted under a state law making it illegal to identify a judge who is under scrutiny by the State Judicial Review Commission.

The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation announced yesterday that it had made a $56 million offer for an interest owned by the Dalco Oil Company, a subsidiary of the Sabine ...
The Wire Service Guild reported last night that its members had ratified a three-year contract with The Associated Press, by a vote of 397 to 337.

Lincoln Center reports that the pipe organ in Alice Tully Hall is in good working order once again. Last Sunday afternoon there was a breakdown that resulted in the last-minute cancellation of a recital by Anton Heiller, the Austrian organist.

But is money the equivalent of speech? This seems a careless equation. There are many political uses of money that are already outlawed. The buying or selling of votes has long been illegal. It is clearly an illegal "corrupt practice" to give or receive money in exchange for an ambassadorship or any other Federal office.

Since every third New Yorker seems to be a cat freak, the current show at the Museum of American Folk Art ought to have great pulling power.

An arbitrator in a dispute between nursing-home employees and the Metropolitan New York Nursing Home Association has ruled that members of the association should pay wage increases to their workers in accordance with their current contract.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UPI) The Army said today that Lieut Gen. Robert L. Fair had been relieved of his command in Europe because his superior disapproved of his leadership techniques and could not change them.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Jan. 16 (AP) An Air Force general relieved of his command for leading a flight of airplanes over a movie set reproduction of the Alamo says that his suspension is "completely unjustified."

The State Consumer Protection Board has petitioned the Public Service Commission for a rehearing on its application for a subpoena to obtain from the Long Island Lighting Company a study comparing its performance with that of 21 other electric utilities.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (Reuters) The Ford Administration announced today that it had chosen a private contractor, E. Systems, Inc., of Dallas, to install and operate the United States monitoring stations in Sinai.

Production workers who are losing their jobs at Rheingold's Brooklyn brewery voted yesterday to accept $1 million in settlement of their unexpired contract with the company, which is shifting its brewing operations to Orange, N.J.
MADRID, Jan. 16 The police rounded up about 120 persons in the Madrid area last night and charged them with planning a general political strike.
LONDON, Jan. 16 Britain, which has been called the sick man of Europe, showed some fragile signs today of economic recovery, but they probably will have little effect on rising unemployment.
Harold V. Schmidt, vice president for plaint design and construction for the Western Electric Company from l957 to 1961, died yesterday at his home in Summit, N.J. He was 79 years old.

Governor Carey yesterday appointed Justice Leonard H. Sandler of State Supreme Court as the new presiding justice for the special grand juries now hearing evidence brought by Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor, on corruption in the criminal justice system.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 16 The officials do make mistakes Pete Rozelle conceded today at a press conference the commissioner of the National Football League held 48 hours in advance of the Super Bowl game. But Rozelle felt that such mistakes were a part of the over-all game and he had no resolutions as how to eliminate the errors.
ROOSEVELT, L.I., Jan. 16 The Roosevelt School District narrowly avoided default last night because of its inability to obtain $3.6 million to pay current debts and employees' salaries.

TRENTON, Jan. 16 David J. Bardin, the state's Commissioner of Environmental Protection, said today the hoped that altering New Jersey's pollution standards would not become a question of "trading lives for jobs."

Eleven major building-maintenance companies and 10 of their top officers were indicted here yesterday on a Federal charge of conspiracy to restrain trade by rigging bids, allocating business and compensating one another for lost customers.

MIAMI, Jan. 16 Only one is a member of the offensive or defensive units. Another is the punter. But the Dallas Cowboys' coach, Tom Landry, says, "Our rookies are the reason we're in the Super Bowl game. Football is confidence, and when you lose such players as Bob Lilly, Calvin Hill, Walt Garrison and Cornell Green, you lose some of your confidence.
Kevin Brown, coming off a two-game absence, scored 14 points tonight, including the decisive basket with 11 seconds to play, as Fordham defeated Cornell, 61-60, at Rose Hill Gymnasium.
LITCHFIELD, Conn., Jan. 16 Two witnesses today at the hearing on a request by Peter Reilly for a new trial in the killing of his mother gave testimony fixing the time of a key telephone call.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) The Justice Department, in a suit filed today, charged one of the nation's largest construction concerns and four related companies with conspiring to boycott individuals and companies blacklisted by Arab nations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 President Ford will propose in his State of the Union and Budget Messages next week an increase in the Social Security tax next year, increased costs and benefits to Medicare patients and a tax break for businesses in areas of high unemployment, informed Administration officials said today.

After a 24-hour visit to Saigon, Senator George McGovern flew back to Hanoi yesterday accompanied by his wife, Eleanor, and four staff members of his Senate Subcomittee on the Near East and South Asia. The South Dakota Democrat conferred in Saigon with Nguyen Thi Binh, foreign minister of the Provisional Revolutionary Government, who gave a dinner for the party. Mrs. Binh was P.R.G. representative at the Paris peace talks.

OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 16 In their fourth National Hockey League game under their new leader, John Ferguson, the New York Rangers suffered their second defeat tonight, taking a 7-0 licking from the California Golden Seals at the Coliseum Arena.
The American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market yesterday registered their third consecutive advance in slower trading.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 Eleven years ago, Robert J. Morgado left Hawaii for the American mainland for the first time in his 21 years and arrived at the State University here as a graduate student in public administration.

A bedroom fire in Norwalk, Conn., took the lives of a 30-year-old woman and a 5-year-old boy she apparently sought to rescue early yesterday, just an hour after firemen had put out a small blaze in the kitchen of the same apartment, Norwalk authorities reported.

CLAREMONT, Calif., Jan. 16 (UPI) Dr. Charles S. Holmes, chairman of the English department at Pomona College and Author of a biography of James Thurber, died yesterday at Pomona Valley Community Hospital. He was 60 years old.

The faculty union of the City University reported a "deluge" of phone calls yesterday from members supporting "militant action" against the State Supreme Court ruling Thursday that upheld the power of the Board of Higher Education to impose a payless furlough on university emloyees.
A pipe bomb exploded at about 4:30 A.M. yesterday outside the Polish Consulate at 233 Madison Avenue, near 38th Street.

The South Dakota Democrat conferred in Saigon with Nguyen Thi Binh, foreign minister of the Provisional Revolutionary Government, who gave a dinner for the party. Mrs. Binh was P.R.G. representative at the Paris peace talks.

Florence Mayo Lacey, a teacher in the public-school system here for 43 years, died Wednesday at Brookdale Hospital Medical Center in Brooklyn. She was 72 years old and lived at 593 Macon Street in Brooklyn.

The state intends to pay a monthly allowance of $291 to parents of retarded patients at the Willowbrook Developmental Center who remove their children from the Staten Island facility and take care of them at home.

Articles about "slum lords" and housing scandals sharply emphasize the propensity of the news media to trot out the usual whipping boys and abuse them mercilessly while refusing even to allude to the underlying causes of housing-program failures.
The problem of vandalism in cemeteries is not susceptible to a single remedy and probably cannot be solved by legistion, State Assemblymen were told yesterday.

Two loans to Bernard Bergman that had been called "questionable" by a Congressional subcommittee were described yesterday as current and "in accordance with safe and sound lending practices" by Federal banking officials.

A prisoner on trial on charges of attempted murder and armed robbery walked out of the Queens House of Detention for Men yesterday morning in place of another inmate who had completed a 15-day sentence for petit larceny but was, he said, asleep at release time.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (UPI) Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, Democrat of Connecticut, announced today that the Senate Government Operations Committee would begin hearings next Wednesday on legislation to reform and control the United States intelligence community.
SHAWNEE-ON-DELAWARE, Pa., Jan. 16 JeanClaude Killy, affectionately referred to as "Le Super Homme" (Superman) when he was winning Alpine ...
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 16 Two Lebanese Air Force jets today attacked leftist and Palestinian forces involved in the siege of a Christian town 12 miles south of here.
Albino Manca, sculptor, whose week includes the giant bronze diving eagle in the World War II memorial in Battery Park, died Thursday at his home, 131 West 11th Street. He was 78 years old.
UNIONDALE, L.I., Jan. 16 The New York Nets won a basketball game and a wrestling match at the Nassau Coliseum tonight.
Tumbling interest rates brought more smiles to already-happy faces on Wall Street yesterday.
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 16 George J. Schulz, since 1966 professor of applied science at Yale University, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at Yale-New Haven Hospital. He was 50 years old.

Notwithstanding its receipt of $48 million from other airlines, under an industry mutual-aid pact, while it was grounded by a 16-day strike, United Airlines said yesterday that on the basis of preliminary accounting it incurred a net loss last month of "almost $20 million."

City officials yesterday asked a private accounting concern hired by the United States Treasury Department to correct what they say is a $400 million error in the company's critique of the city's fiscal health.

Lincoln Center reports that the pipe organ in Alice Tully Hall is in good working order once again. Last Sunday afternoon there was a breakdown that resulted in the last-minute cancellation of a recital by Anton Heiller, the Austrian organist.

Two elderly sisters terrorized by a gang of youths in the South Bronx earlier this week were eligible for nearly $150 a month more than the combined income of $186 that they were receiving from Social Security, city officials said yesterday. One of the sisters died following the assault.

TRENTON, Jan. 16 Governor Byrne tacked notices of future governmental meetings on a new bulletin board in the Secretary of State's office today, marking the official observance of the state's new "Sunshine Law."

Mary Orr, an author as well as an actress, once wrote a story called "The Wisdom of Eve," which Joseph Mankiewicz transformed into the movie classic "All About Eve," Miss Orr's new play, "Grass Widows," which opened Thursday at Stage 73, desperately needs Mr. Mankiewicz but it is not worth his, or anyone's time.

Sir Rudolf Bing of Columbia Artists, sponsors of Miss Tebaldi's recital told a disappointed but sympathetic crowd that he hoped to reschedule the soprano in 10 days to two weeks.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 16 (AP) The Pittsburgh Penguins, who have not won in their last seven games, discharged Coach Marc Boileau tonight.

Despite a rising divorce rate and other evidence of trouble, the family remains society's most basic and most cherished institution. One recent survey showed that among people 30 and over, 87 percent still choose "a happy family life" as their most important goal.
MONTREAL, Jan. 16 (AP) A contract settlement between the Canadian Paperworkers Union and the Eastern Canada Newsprint Group appears imminent, an industry source said today.

Throughout the first part of this book, Henry Fairlie sounds like a Spiro Agnew with brains. He is critical of the "permissiveness" that spawned Jerry Rubin. He does not, like Agnew, blame all our troubles on Dr. Spock.

John Bradley Cumings of Toronto and Mrs. Gardner Gregg of Aspen. Colo., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alexandra Perry Cumings of Brookline, Mass., to David Ignatius Sullivan, son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Leavitt' Sullivan of Newton, Mass.
It is one of the prime generalizations in sports that we should "play the percentages."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 The revolution has gone profession al. No more smudgy mimeographed fliers, childish flagburnings and hokey chants against imperialism. Now the revolution is a slick and scientific effort, with costly public opinion surveys, smoothly written books, $20 library kits, hired political consultants and artful newspaper ads.

Mark H. Brown of Stamford, Conn., has announced the engagement of his daughter Katheryne Elizabeth Brown, to David G. Colman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Colman of Plainview, L.I.A July wedding is planned.

The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has approved a 1976 budget calling for the expenditure of $224 million for construction projects, $336 million for daily operations and $180 million for debt service on outstanding bonds.
ALBANY, Jan. 17 (AP) The State Budget Division yesterday released the names of seven top officials who are losing their telephones in state cars under an economy move.
UNIONDALE John F. Kennedy had his Vaughn Meader, Humphrey Bogart his Rich Little, and Richard M. Nixon his David Frye. And now for the zany Marx Brothers, add Palmer, Leon and Kriegsman.
Judge John A. Ackerman of the Appellate Division of the New Jersey Superior Court died of cancer Friday at his home in Mountainside, N.J. He was 61 years old.

10 A.M. (Channel 4) "Sunday": Guests include Representatives Bella S. Abzug and Elizabeth Holtzman of New York and Helen Meyner of New Jersey, all Democrats; and Morris Abram, chairman of the Moreland Commission.

WASHINGTON One of President Ford's senior campaign aides said he nearly drove his car off Massachusetts Avenue the other day while guffawing at a radio news account that Rogers C.B. Morton was being appointed White House counselor on domestic and economic issues.

MIAMI BEACH, Jan. 17 The Pro Bowl, the National Football League's all-star game, became an endangered species today. The game is scheduled next Sunday in New Orleans, but it's conceivable the selected players may vote not to play in it.
LANDOVER, Md. Jan. 17 (AP) Elvin Hayes poured in 22 points tonight in leading the streaking Washington Bullets to a 105-103 victory over Philadelphia in a National Basketball Association contest.

Watching Violette Verdy and Peter Martins on Friday night in Jerome Robbins's Chopin ballet, "In the Night," brought to mind the lament by Alexander Pushkin that the mazurka was not what it used to be. The Russian poet's complaint, in "Eugene Onegin." was that the gentry had salonized a once-vital folk dance, Men, he said, now glided like women.

Seven public libraries were added yesterday to the casualty list of public facilities such as firehouses and police stations that have ceased operation because of the city's fiscal problems.

The day after his triumph and the Flyers' 4-to-1 triumph over the Soviet Army squad was incontestably a triumph of coaching Fred Shero sat in the cubicle that passes for his office in the Philadelphia Spectrum, explaining how a North American hockey team had finally beaten the champion of oblivion.
An 84-year-old woman who had been bound and gagged, apparently by a robber, was found dead last night in her fifth-floor apartment in the Yorkville section of Manhattan.
WASHINGTON Two things can be said with confidence about the Federal Budget to be sent to Congress this week by President Ford.

Condensation inside the house can not only lead to the development of mildew and hard-to-get-rid-of musty odors in closed off or unheated spaces, it can also cause staining of plaster, peeling of paint and rotting of wood structural members. Alberto Giacometti died on Jan. 11, 1966, at the age of 64. To mark the 10th anniversary of that event, the Sidney Janis Gallery has organized an excellent exhibition of his work over 50 sculptures, paintings and drawings selected from the copious oeuvre the artist produced during the last 20 years of his life, the period of his return to "tradition" after the "Babylonian captivity," as he called it, of his alliance with the Surrealists.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 Steel union and industry leaders expressed satisfaction today with the decision late last night by the Government's International Trade Commission recommending that President Ford impose quotas on imports of stainless steel and other alloy "specialty" steels.
LONDON, Jan. 15 (AP) The chimes of Big Ben will be si lenced next week while painters work in a room containing striking mechanisms, weights that, swing out to within an inch of the wall.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 Some members of the Newspaper Guild at The Washington Post, who have angered their own and other labor unions by crossing picket lines and continuing to work during a bitter 15-week strike by the newspaper's craft workmen, are drawing plans for a mass withdrawal from the guild.
LISBON, Jan. 18 A military proposal for continued rule by the armed forces until 1980 was opposed today by Portugal's three main non-Communist political parties.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 17 A drought across the pampas, Argentina's vast plains, has dealt a severe setback to the country's hopes for a bumper harvest of grain this year that would help to pay off heavy foreign debts.

Robin Roberts and Bob Lemon, the major leagues' top winning pitchers during the 1950's, are the leading candidates for election to the Hall of Fame Thursday when the Baseball Writers Association of America announces its 1976 selections to the Cooperstown, N.Y., shrine.

With the demise, unlamented, of the United States Postal Service's proposed issue of 32 stamps reproducing the complete Declaration of Independence, a question came to mind what, if anything, would one like to see in its place. This in turn led to a larger question what Bicentennial stamps would one have liked in addition to or instead of what the USPS is putting out.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 17 After four years without an "F" to blot their academic records, Yale University undergraduates next fall will once again have failing grades put into their transcripts for flunked courses.

SHIRI-MATUNDA, Tanzania A village has sprouted here on land that was uninhabited and untilled five years ago. It has a school, a food cooperative, a dispensary and a cluster of neat, single-unit dwellings for 200 families.

This weekend the first phase of a most interesting theatricel experiment is ending the Colonnades Theater Lab in Lafayette Street, just opposite Joseph Papp's Public Theater, is concluding its first repertory season, and, more importantly, ish preparing for its next.
SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 17 The announcement by President Park Chung Hee that oil has been discovered in South Korea has sent spasins of excitement across the country.
MINEOLA The Board of Supervisors is to vote tomorrow on a resolution to cut tuition aid to Nassau students attending branches of the City University of New York.
ALBANY, Jan. 17 Schools in New York State have just ended their worst year in recent history in terms of labor strife, and this year promises to be even worse, according to school experts here.

BERCHTESGADEN, West Germany, Jan. 17 (UPI) A spill by her French rival, Patricia Emonet, helped Christa Zechmeister of West Germany win a women's World Cup slalom ski race today, her first victory on the current circuit.

A long-planned electronic revolution in the nation's longdistance telephone system began yesterday in Chicago as the first of a network of computer-controlled call-switching equipment went into service.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 17 (AP) A meeting of about 100 lawyers, educators, journalists and intellectuals scheduled for today to take up Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's suggestion for a thorough discussion on possible changes in the Constitution was not held.
The Communications Workers of America, which used to have one political action committee, transferred $104,000 last summer to its 12 districts to set up a political action committee in each.
Right Mind, a 5-year-old horse who was trained by a man who was trained by Vince Lombardi, ran to daylight yesterday and captured the $54,450 Aqueduct Handicap at the Big Arctic.

IOWA CITY Although the first primary election, in New Hampshire, is still more than a month away, the nation is about to receive, in Iowa, a tentative first indication of popular preferences in this year's Presidential election campaign.
Mr. and Mrs. ,Tames T. Morris of Salt Point, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their niece, Joyce Ann McNeill, to Peter Codyre Harkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Harkins of Greenwich, Conn.

A new, deliberately unsentimental and unromantic version of one of Ibsen's classics, "Peer Gynt" adapted and directed by Howard Da Silva, the actor, is now having its premiere by the Stage Company at Queensborough Community College.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 17 (UPI) An attorney for Patricia Hearst tonight labeled as "unconstitutional" a Federal judge's threat to impose sanctions against her defense team if she failed to cooperate with a Government psychiatrist.

The stock market last week posted a net gain of 18.50 points, and along the way set all kinds of records, including the most volume for any week's trading 159.6 million shares compared with the previous high of 145.68 million shares traded in the week ended Jan. 31, 1975.

ORADELL A visitor driving along Kinderkamack Road here last week missed the unobtrusive entrance to Riverdell Hospital and, when he realized he had gone too far, stopped to ask a group of telephone repairmen for directions.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 17 Richard M. Nixon testified in a closed session at San Clemente that he never personally selected the persons to be wiretapped under an operation of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in 1969 to find the sources of leaks of information, associates of the former President said today.

BROOKVILLE The Sixth Annual Hicksville American Indoor Soccer Tournament is nearing the half-way mark at Long Island Lutheran High School here and before it is over more than 300 games will have been played.

Wendy Martha Watson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Lowell Watson of Easton, Pa., formerly of Forest Hills, Queens, was married yesterday morning to Dr. John Louis Varriano of Amherst, Mass., son of Dr. and Mrs. John Varriano of Jersey City.

When I first came to live in Los Angeles four years ago my 7-year-old son came home from school one day, telling me of having made a new friend, a boy in his class whose father was a movie writer. "And what did you tell your new friend I did?" I asked. "I said," said my son, "that you were a regular writer."

Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger is finally taking his trip to Moscow this week to discuss a nuclear arms control agreement, the Middle East and the involvement of both the United States and the Soviet Union in the Angolan civil war. The fourth unlisted item on the agenda, however, is the most serious one: The two nations' different views of the essential nature and parameters of their mutual policy of detente.

LONDON, Jan. 17 (UPI) Scenes of kissing and hugging between players celebrating a goal have become a familiar sight on the world soccer circuit, but moves are under way to ban the practice in England.

STORMVILLE, N.Y.: Jan. 17 Three prisoners and two guards sat at a table in a large meeting room in Green Haven prison. Facing them sat another prisoner, Frank Lott, wearing a green stateissue jacket and pants and a black knit cap.
MIAMI, Jan. 17 Everyone knows about the Pittsburgh Steelers' defensive front four, a gargantuan group that is as menacing and intimidating as a street gang in a dark alley.

JERSEY CITY, Jan. 17 (UPI) Mayor Paul T. Jordan joined 2,500 policemen here today to pay final tribute to Patrolman William McCarthy, who was fatally stabbed Wednesday when he tried to stop several men who were tampering with a car a block from his home.

HUNTINGTON A full-sized replica of a Revolutionary War whaleboat, complete with bow-mounted cannon, is slowly being constructed in the barn behind the Historical Society headquarters here. When the boat is completed it is to be used in races on Long Island Sound with a smaller vessel now being built in Darien Conn.

The acquisition by Israel of four advanced radar surveillance aircraft from the United States if approved by Congress will augment Israeli air superiority over any combination of Arab air forces, according to United States and Israeli officers.

MIAMI, Jan. l9--When Mean Joe Greene reported to the Pittsburgh Steelers' training camp in 1974, their defensive line coach, George Perles, told him "We've got a rookie who's so mean, he doesn't even like himself." The rookie was Jack Lambert, the middle linebacker who has now been a central character on two Super Bowl championship teams in two years. "It's no accident," says a Steeler official. "He put the finishing touch on our defensive unit."

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 19--A Federal judge ruled here today that Milwaukee schools were segregated, and ordered immediate steps for integration.

Mayor Beame yesterday announced the abolition of the Transportation Administration and the Youth Services Agency, and the division of their functions among new city agencies, a reorganization that he said would result in the layoff of 90 city workers and a savings of $3.9 million a year.

LONDON, Jan. 19 (AP)--Sir Ronald Edwards, chairman since last October of the restructured British Leyland car and truck manufacturing company and president of the Beecham pharmaceutical group, died in a hospital here last night. He was 62 years old.

State Senator John J. Moore, a Democrat representing the 14th district in Queens, died Sunday night after apparently suffering a heart attack at his home, 22-48 80th Street, Jackson Heights. He was 55 years old.

Diane Stricof Rosenberg, a lawyer who was a hearing officer with the Housing Authority and a referee with the Parking Violations Bureau, died Sunday in Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 37 years old and lived at 84 St. John's Avenue in Yonkers.

Concerned with the city's ability to monitor its own attempt at fiscal recovery, United States Treasury officials have decided to seek tighter, more coordinated procedures next week at a meeting with representatives of the General Accounting Office and the state's Emergency Financial Control Board.
LISBON, Tuesday, Jan. 20-- A military commission has formally impicated the Communist Party and several extreme leftist groups in the coup attempt of last November.
Alan R, Gruber has been appointed president of the Equity Funding Corporation of America, Robert M. Loeffler, trustee of the company, Robert M. Loeffler, trustee of the company, announced yesterday.

Burlington Northern Inc. reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter of 1975 almost doubled, but for the full year, net income of the big diversified rail system was down by more than 37 percent from the preceding year.
The temperature of 7 in Central Park at 7:20 A.M. yesterday didn't break the record low for the date (1; in 1875), but it was still cold enough to make 25 at 3 P.M. feel like a break in the weather.

A panel of educators appointed by the American Federation of Teachers declared yesterday that last fall's budget cuts had stripped the city schools of vital programs and services and were turning them into mere "custodial institutions."

A court-ordered racial quota for school principals here was overturned yesterday by a Federal appeals court that called it "constitutionally forbidden reverse discrimination."
Charles Reich, one of the largest mink dealers in New York raised his hand yesterday at the Emba mutation mink auctions at the Hudson's Bay Company and bought a bundle of mink skins at $44 a skin.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (UPI) --President Ford's top lawyer promised the Federal Election Commission today a detailed breakdown of Rogers C.B. Morton's activities as a White House adviser to help the commission decide if Mr. Morton should remain on the Federal payroll.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--The Food and Drug Administration said today that it was banning Red No. 2, the nation's most widely used dye in foods, drugs and cosmetics, because of new concern that it might be a cancer-causing agent.

There is a new concert hall in New York--nestled among the second-floor galleries at the Jewish Museum --and an interesting new chamber series incorporating elements of the state-supported "Meet the Composers" programs.

NEWARK, Jan. 19--Medicaid cuts in New Jersey began taking their physical and emotional toll among the poor in this city today.

Paine Webber Inc., parent company of the brokerage firm of Paine Webber Jackson Curtis, reported yesterday that profits for its December quarter fell nearly 19 percent despite a 16 percent rise in revenues.

The winner of the seventh world correspondence championship, which ran from 1972 to 1975, was Yakob Estrin of the Soviet Union. Zagorovsky of the Soviet Union, and Richardson of England, each with 11 points.

Leonard H. Sandler, the newly appointed special justice hearing cases brought by Maurice H. Nadjari, spent part of his first day on the job yesterday conferring with the special state prosecutor about pending prosecutions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19-- Democratic senators and representatives indicated tonight that President Ford's proposals to hold the line on the Federal budget would not fare too well in the election-year Congress.

A decade ago--before the days of Michael Bennett, Harold Prince or even, in a way, Bob Fosse--the leading Broadway director in the musical theater was Jerome Robbins. And, in absentia, he still is. Most producers with a musical on their hands routinely, if with bleak hope, offer it to Mr. Robbins first.
INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 19 (UPI)--Top-seeded Arthur Ashe defeated Vitas Gerulaitis, 6-2, 6-7, 6-4, tonight and captured his second straight World Championship Tennis tourney.

OTTAWA, Jan. 19--Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, defending himself against charges of socialism and authoritarianism, asked Canadian business and labor tonight to collaborate with the Government in programs to cure the nation's economic ills.

Four youths, all students at Chelsea Vocational High School, were arrested yesterday on charges ranging from sexual abuse to criminal mischief after an IND subway train was vandalized near the West Fourth Street station.
Soybean prices rose yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade under the impact of some new speculative buying handled through leading commission houses.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--One comes from New York to Washington these days with a genuine sense of humility. This is rare in Washington--a genuine sense of humility. All politicians here are humble, of course, and seldom let you forget it. They go around the country boasting about their humility. They are proud of their humility. Many are downright arrogant about their humility and insist that it qualifies them to be President.

MIAMI, Jan. 19--Chuck Noll, the 43-year-old coach of the Pittsburgh Steelers who played in the National Football League for seven seasons with some distinction, today defended the aggressiveness of his team in yesterday's Super Bowl game. The Dallas Cowboys, who lost to the Steelers, 2117, thought the victors were overly and unnecessarily aggressive, especially Mel Blount, the cornerback.

Barnett Lambert, executive director of Associated Camps Inc. and associate general director of the Associated Young Men's Young Women's Hebrew Associations of Greater New York, died Thursday on a visit to Jerusalem. He was 64 years bid and lived in Eastchester, N.Y.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 19--The Rev. David N. Bubar, the Fundamentalist minister who claims psychic powers, was convicted here today of charges that he masterminded the bombing last year of a sponge rubber factory in Shelton, Conn.

Looking for a gift or an accessory to add a fillip to that tired winter wardrobe, or a little pizazz to your decor? You may very well find what you want in your own neighborhood, for the city is rich in offbeat shops offering merchandise 'that is out of the ordinary.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19-- President Ford has asked W.J. Usery, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, to take over the post of Secretary of Labor, succeeding John T. Dunlop, who resigned last week, an informed White House official reported tonight.
PAGE, Ariz.--If the Glen Canyon Dam here on the Colorado River were suddenly blown up by saboteurs, Edward Abbey, the novelist, might have to take a bit of the blame--or the credit.

The Federal Communications Commission approved yesterday an increase in the longdistance telephone rates of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company that is expected to cost its customers. an additional $225 million a year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19-- President Ford, declaring that "common sense" dictated a selfdisciplined course at the outset of the third American century, called tonight on Congress to act with restraint in meeting the immediate needs and expectations of the nation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--The Central, Intelligence Agency has systematically undervalued, in some cases by half, the military equipment supplied to warring factions in Angola, according to evidence obtained by the House Select Committee on Intelligence.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19-- President Ford proposed tonight the enactment of a new type of tax benefit designed to encourage more people to buy common stocks.
MADRID, Jan. 19--The Government today drafted some 70,000 railroad workers after one of Spain's biggest waves of strikes in 40 years began to disrupt train service.

HELSINGOR, Denmark, Jan. 19--European Socialist leaders concluded a two-day meeting today sharply divided over political links with Communists and uncertain about what tactics to use to counter Communist influence in Italy and Portugal.

JERUSALEM, Wednesday, Jan. 20--Israeli officials expressed deep concern yesterday over the intensified fighting and political chaos in Lebanon, but both civilian and military sources contended that Israel would not intervene unless Syria did so first.

ARANYAPRATHET, Thailand, Jan. 19 Hundreds of thousands of people are being moved from one part of Cambodia to another, frequently at gunpoint, in a migration that rivals the forced evacuation from Phnom Penh last April, according to Western intelligence sources and interviews here with scores of refugees, some of whom escaped from convoys.

LONDON, Jan. 20 The House of Commons today rejected a bill to abolish corporal punishment in Britain's schools "one of the last vestiges of legalized violence in our society today," according to the bill's sponsor.
The National News Council yesterday proposed formation of a joint committee of journalists and lawyers to concern itself with the question of gag orders issued by judges against the press.

Senate and House committee leaders agreed yesterday on a $6 billion modified bill to revive the nation's collapsing railroad system and indicated that President Ford was prepared to sign the legislation.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 20-The foreign ministers of the Common Market said today that they were ready to resume trade talks with Spain following recent indications from Foreign Minister Jose Maria de Areilza that his Government would pursue a more liberal political policy.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 20 Israeli Government sources said today that Palestine Liberation Army forces in Lebanon appeared to have been reinforced during the last 24 hours by Palestinian troops from Syria. But they said that reports of up to 15,000 additional men seemed grossly exaggerated.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 20 (UPI) The price of gold plunged by more than $4 an ounce today, closing for the second straight day at its lowest point in two years. The dollar, however, reversed yesterday's losses on European exchanges and returned to pre-weekend levels.

ROME, Jan. 20 (Reuters) The former president of the Gulf Oil Corporation's Italian subsidiary said in a magazine interview that the company paid more than $600,000 to the Christian Democrat and Socialist parties from 1969 to 1972.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 20 Albert Fondy, president, and 17 other leaders of the striking Pittsburgh Federation of Teachers were ordered today to appear in court Thursday to show cause why they should not be jailed for defying a back-to work order.

SAN DIEGO, Jan. 20 (AP) Harland Svare was dismissed today as general manager of the San Diego Chargers, a post he held since 1971, and he immediately blamed a psychiatrist's book about him. [In New Orleans, Hank Stram signed a $1 millionplus, five-year contract as head coach of the Saints.]

Senator Barry Goldwater said yesterday that the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence went too far in its investigation into the Central Intelligence Agency and should have spent more time looking into the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 After a briefing by President Ford on his 1977 budget today, a bipartisan group of governors and mayors voiced strong support of the President's plans to give the states a freer hand in spending Federal funds for social programs.

MOSCOW, Jan. 20 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger arrived in a light snow today for a crucial round of talks with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, that both sides hope will break the deadlock in negotiations for an accord limiting each side's long-range missiles and bombers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 The economy's recovery from recession proceeded at a good pace in the fourth quarter of last year, though less than half the big spurt in the third quarter, the Commerce Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 The Supreme Court ruled by a vote of 5 to 3 today that heavy caseloads in the Federal courts were not a good enough reason for Federal judges to send cases off to less-burdened state courts for trial.

BOSTON, Jan. 20 (AP) About 300 persons, including 100 pupils, demonstrated against forced busing at East Boston High School today for about two hours before policemen dispersed them. The police said that two persons had been arrested on disorderly conduct charges.

The judge presiding in the murder trial of Robert C. (Sonny) Carson and five other defendants yesterday put in written form his previous oral order against reporting the criminal background of the defendants.

President Ford received some applause and some criticism yesterday from a cross section of economists and businessmen asked yesterday about how they viewed the proposals in his State of the Union message.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 Arena Stage, long recognized as a pioneer in the regional theater movement, is now getting its audience into the act with the production of four manuscript works still in the process of development.

OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 20 (UPI) Barbara N. Armstrong, believed to have been the first woman law professor in the United States, died Sunday. She was 85 years old.

CAIRO, Jan. 20 Chances of collective mediation by Arab governments in the Lebanese conflict appeared to remain slim today in spite of a new call by Mahmoud Riad, Secretary General of the Arab League, for an emergency meeting of Arab heads of state.

PARAMUS, Jan. 21 The stars of "Over Here," which opens Friday night at the Playhouse here on the Bergen Mall, have a problem.

Laurence Olivier will be the artistic director and host of a series of dramas by 20th-century American playwrights to be produced by Granada Television of Britain and carried here by NBC-TV as "A Tribute to American Theater."

Lewis S. Rosenstiel, founder of Schenley Industries Inc., the giant liquor corporation, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Miami Beach at the age of 84. He suffered a stroke in 1971 and was partly paralyzed.

Leon Greenberg, who was president of Monticello Raceway, was fined $9,000 yesterday for fraudulently using $4,856 of the raceway's money to pay for his son's bar mitzvah at Grossinger's the resort hotel in the Catskils.

City officials and trustees of the New York Public Library yesterday developed a tentative plan that would, if approved, result in the reopening of seven branch libraries that were closed as an austerity measure last week.
DAMUR, Lebanon, Jan. 21 This once proud town of 15,000 Christians, perched on a hill overlooking orange groves and the Mediterranean, is a smoking ruin.
Twelve of the nation's 50 largest bank holding companies, widely scattered across the country, were placed on a confidential "problem" list by the staff of the Federal Reserve Board a year ago.
CANBERRA, Australia, Jan. 21 (AP) Australia's new Liberal Party Government today restored "God Save the Queen" as an Australian national anthem.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 Pursuing the theme of "energy independence," President Ford's budget proposed a 30 percent increase in spending for energy programs in fiscal year 1977, to a record $10.4 billion.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 President Ford sent Congress today proposed reductions of $20 billion in Federal programs and promised additional tax reduction if Congress accepted his plan.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange finished slightly lower yesterday, while those in the over-the-counter market closed higher.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) President Ford, in his budget request to Congress today, asked $298.5 million for the programs of the 13-state Appalachian Regional Commission.

"We consider Manhattan to be our largest foreign market and the last one we plan to enter," said Frank Carney, President of the Pizza Hut fastfood chain, when asked if he planned to open here this year.
CHERRY HILL, Jan. 21 Alcoholism is increasing more rarapidly among women than men, authorities said today, but treatment for women is lacking because many facilities exclude women.

The Monsanto Company, producers of chemicals, textiles and consumer products, reported yesterday that fourthquarter earnings were up 70.6 percent, but that the net for all of last year was down 5.4 percent, reflecting declines in the second and third quarters.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 21-The Palestine Liberation Army, which came into being in its present form 10 years ago, is the military arm of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

KANSAS CITY, Jan. 21 (UPI) Derek Sanderson scored while St. Louis was two men short in the second period tonight and assisted on a first-period power-play goal in leading the St. Louis Blues to a 4-2 National Hockey League victory over Kansas City, hours after Bep Guidolin, the Scouts' coach, resigned.
Shaking off profit taking and edginess over developments abroad, the stock market trimmed early losses in continued active trading yesterday and closed moderately lower.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 For the first time in more than a decade, a new proposed Federal budget contains no increase in appropriation for the National Cancer Institute, the agency that manages the nation's research war against cancer.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 21 Taking the stand in her own defense, Jo Anne Brown startled the courtroom today when she replied "yes and no," when asked if she had killed Burr Hollister, a State Supreme Court law secretary with whom she had lived in Uniondale.

Many children revel in the words of Polly Chase Boyden's poem which begins: "Mud is very nice to feel." The musical play, "Dirty Ferdie Comes Clean," goes further. Ferdie dreams that he is in a place where he never has to take a bath or otherwise concern himself with cleanliness. He dutifully learns, however, that it's better to come clean.
Many banking officers expressed surprise yesterday when informed that their company had been listed a year ago on a Federal Reserve tabulation of "problem" banks.
Two of the nation's largest airlines, Trans World Airlines and American Airlines, reported yesterday massive deficits for the fourth quarter of 1975 and for the full year.

MANILA, Jan. 21 President Ferdinand E. Marcos today created a national people's council to advise him on legislative matters under his martiallaw rule and announced that there would be no elections in the immediate future.
BAHRAIN, Jan. 21 Two Concorde jets, taking off simultaneously from London and Paris, today inaugurated the world's first scheduled supersonic passenger services.
TRENTON, Jan. 21 Governor Byrne today repeated a pledge he made when he first took office two years ago to make the closing of the Trenton State Prison "a monument to my administration."

Chile's most respected political leader of recent times, former President Eduardo Frei, has delivered a savage attack on the military dictatorship of Gen. Augusto Pinochet and projected a "democratic alternative" for that stricken country. In effect, Mr. Frei calls on the armed forces to throw out the governing junta in order to prevent a regime "with many totalitarian characteristics" from being fastened on Chile.

In a surprise action, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday a series of executive changes, including the early retirement of its president, Robert D. Lilley, and the election of two vice chairmen.

MONTREAL, Jan. 21 (UPI) Members of the Canadian Paperworkers Union who are employees of four Quebec paper mills have ratified a new three-year agreement to end a three-month-long strike, it was announced today.

Another city attempt to encourage construction a proposal for the commercial development of a block on Second Avenue from 58th to 59th Streets has a sounder design and planning base; unfortunately it is bogged down in community opposition.

The European Zonal B Tournament in Barcelona was won by Genna Sosonko of the Netherlands, who finished a half point ahead of Jesus Diez del Corral of Spain, the second-prize winner. These two players thus qualified for berths in the twin Interzonal Tournaments to be held this summer in Switzerland and the Philippines.

TRENTON, Jan. 21 A special commission from labor and industry appointed by Governor Byrne to suggest ways to improve New Jersey's economy reported today that a state income tax was essential and that the lack of it was a major factor blocking an economic recovery.

A group of parents who have kept 11 children out of city schools since September in the belief the education provided there is "harmful and destructive," pressed the Board of Education yesterday to give the money it would have spent on the children to schools of the parents' choice.

For its initial American programming venture of this anniversary year, the Carnegie Hall Corporation inaugurated, on Tuesday night, a five-event Bicentennial Chamber Music Series in Carnegie Recital Hall.

Under intense pressure from City Hall, the head of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, Dr. John L.S. Holloman Jr., has recommended a substantial start toward scaling down the overblown municipal hospital system.

A witness who testified yesterday that all six defendants at the murder trial of Robert C. (Sonny) Carson had been present the night a 34-year-old Brooklyn man was fatally shot gave conflicting versions of what he had seen.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 President Ford's budget today contained a detailed explanation of "what went wrong" in the budget year that ended last June 30 to convert an originally estimated deficit of $9.4 billion to an actual deficit of $43.6 billion.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 Included in the President's budget request for the Department of Health, Education and Welfare is money for 150 new staff members for the Office of Civil Rights.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 Congressional experts on budgetary matters predicted today that Congress would reject many of the proposals outlined by President Ford in his budget.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 The Ford Administration has worked out a legislative formula to avoid most of a staggering, if highly theoretical, outlay of $440 billion to eradicate water pollution from the country.
Dr. S. Evans Ganz, an ear, nose and throat surgeon and teacher, died Monday evening at Lenox Hill Hospital of a heart attack. He was 69 years old and lived at 300 East 74th Street.

LONDON, Jan. 21 (AP) The dollar gained strength today in Europe, aided by weakness in the Italian lira and French franc. Gold inched up a bit on European bullion exchanges but was far from recouping yesterday's sharp losses.

Dee Dee Bridgewater, who won a Tony Award last season for her performance in "The Wiz," is taking a new step in an already impressive career at the Cafe at Hopper's, Avenue of the Americas at 11th Street.

Substantial declines in fourth quarter operating earnings were announced yesterday by the Chemical New York Corporation, the Bankers Trust New York Corporation and the First Chicago Corporation, which are among the largest bank holding companies in the nation.

Ed Reichick, who owns a liquor store in the St. George ferry terminal on Staten Island, was slumped in a chair at the shoemaker's shop across the hall the other night, shaking his head with obvious dismay.

Alvan Adams, the Phoenix Suns' center, will be the only first-year player in the National Basketball Association All-Star game on Feb. 3 at the Spectrum in Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 The draft-Humphrey movement has run into legal problems with the Federal Election Commission and has suspended, at least temporarily, plan to raise campaign funds to promote the nomination of the Minnesota Senator.

The exhibition rooms on the mezzanine of the normally sedate Roosevelt Hotel are echoing with sounds of the midnight hour this week.

WASHINGTON The World Bank has before it a proposal to lend $33 million to the Chilean Government for investment in copper-mining facilities. The bank's president, Robert S. McNamara, has recommended the loan. It is scheduled to go before the board of directors for final approval next Tuesday.

Rossini's "Il Barbiere di Siviglia,' which had its fifth performance of the season at the Metropolitan Opera on Tuesday night, is one of the supreme challenges of any company's ensemble playing. Sterett-Gittings Kelsey names her sculptures at random after friends and relations, a custom she initiated with her first big show in Greenwich, Conn., five years ago. Leaders of the National Black Political Assembly announced yesterday that they intended to draft State Senator Julian S. Bond of Georgia as an independent candidate for President of the United States.
BOSTON, Jan. 21 (UPI) Black and white students fought with fists and chairs at Hyde Park High School today and the School Superintendent, Marion Fahey, ordered the school closed tomorrow.

A surplus of dried milk in Europe had an impact on soybean and soybean product prices in Chicago yesterday. As a result, prices were virtually unchanged.

The Weyherheauser Company, the largest factor in lumber and wood products, and major producers of pulp, paper and containers, reported yesterday an increase of 36.8 percent in fourth-quarter earnings, the first gain in a year and a half. Annual earnings were down 31 percent from 1974 on a 4 percent dip in sales.
A police lieutenant and his brother, a police sergeant, and a newsstand they bought are the subjects of an investigation growing out of a 1973 Civil Service test for lieutenant.

Only Bess Myerson could defeat Ramsey Clark, according to a series of hypothetical match-ups for the Democratic nomination for Senator from New York. The match-ups were made in a poll commissioned by the Democratic State committee, according to politicians who say they are familiar with the results.

The focus of the question of alleged political corruption in the Bronx swung back yesterday to the effort by Patrick J. Cunningham, the state Democratic chairman, to quash a subpoena ordering him to testify before a grand jury.

Smallpox vaccination is now almost as extinct as the disease the immunization was designed to prevent.

The American tour of the Who begins its second leg March 9 in Boston, continues the next night to Madison Square Garden, and winds up March 27 and 28 in the 5,400-scat Winterland Auditorium in San Francisco.

Disston Inc. of Pittsburgh, a manufacturer of hand and garden tools, said yesterday that it had been advised by the Swedish steel company, Sandvik A.B., that the Swedish concern planned to buy about 2 million of Disston shares at $13 a share.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 28 Gilbert Kingan, retired Unitet States manager of the London and Lancashire Insurance Company of Liverpool, England, died yesterday at Greenwich Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 1 Putnam Hill.

RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 28 (AP) About 160 people were believed drowned in the sinking of a ferryboat after it and a fishing trawler collided in the Andaman Sea off southern Burma Monday night, the Government newspaper, Working People's Daily, reported today.
TORONTO, Jan. 28 The Islanders and the Toronto Maple Leafs played a sputtering hockey game tonight, finally won by the New York club 3-2, on a goal in the final minutes by Ralph Stewart.

Despite all denials, Governor Carey's proposed $110 million cut in operating aid to local school districts sounds suspiciously like a bargaining card for higher state taxes. For those districts already at or near the austerity level of school financing, the reduction in state aid makes higher local property taxes the only alternative to curtailed educational services. The threat of such local tax rises may well be intended to make higher state taxes more palatable.

One million children run away every year, according to informed sources, and Christine Chapman, an English teacher and mother of two teen-age sons, spent three years trying to find out why. She traveled around the country interviewing runaways, their families, their friends, the police, and various public and private agencies. In "America's Runaways," she tells us what she found. She also tells us what she feels, and sometimes the two are difficult to separate.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 30-Indonesia, faced with dwindling markets and a sharp decline in demand for its oil, has begun to negotiate government-to-government oil sales at substantially lower prices than the current levels set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, according to oil-company executives and Western diplomats reached by telephone in Jakarta.

OLEAN, N.Y., Jan. 30 (AP) The Rev. Francis W. Kearney, a professor of philosophy who was president of St. Bonaventure University for almost six years in the 1960's, collapsed and died today. He was 63 years old.

Governor Carey urged last night that the State Bar Association take a more active role in disciplining "errant" prosecutors.

To many New Yorkers born since World War II, ships are what sailed on Central Park's artificial ponds each Sunday. And to older Manhattanites, the marine traditions of this island have been increasingly obscured as the roar of jet aircraft replaced the husky blasts of boat whistles.
INNSBRUCK, Austria, Jan. 30 (AP) The eight-member United States men's Alpine ski team moved into the Olympic Village earlier than expected today, scrapping plans for a pre-Games training camp.

The garment workers union reported some progress in dress-industry negotiations yesterday as the two sides intensified their efforts to reach agreement and avert a strike threatened for Monday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 president Ford declared this evening that Mr. Reagan's accusation of "dirty tricks" by the Ford campaign orgarnization was "without foundation."

McLEAN, Va., Jan. 30 President Ford promised officials of the Central Intelligence Agency today that he would work to restore public confidence in the intelligence community without compromising its effectiveness or secrets.

Mary Jo Risher, the lesbian mother who recently lost custody of her 9-year-old son to her former husband in a jury trial in Dallas, vowed here yesterday that she would fight the decision in the courts.

MANILA, Jan. 30 Philippine Army troops detained more than 200 striking workers today as part of one of the biggest crackdowns since President Ferdinand E. Marcos declared martial law over three years ago, eyewitnesses reported.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 A Swede, a Dutchman and two Americans battled their way into the semifinals of the United States pro indoor tennis championships tonight. The top prize for the men's singles event is $20,000.

AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 30 (UPI) Researchers of unidentified flying objects say there is nothing phenomenal about a strange hot dogshaped object photographed recently over Clovis, N.M. They say it is only a blurred picture of the planet Saturn.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Jan. 31-The Security Council unanimously approved a resolution today calling for United Nations-supervised elections in South-West Africa and condemning South Africa's use of the territory "as a base for attacks on neighboring countries."
The United Federation of Teachers lost a court effort yesterday to stop the Board of Education from recalling about 1,100 teachers from sabbatical leaves when the spring school term begins Monday.

Wheat futures dominated the market in light trading yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, with final prices up about 7 cents a bushel. The March delivery closed at $3.50 a bushel, up from $3.43. Corn and soybeans were virtually unchanged.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP) Prices farmers get for raw agricultural products declined one-half of 1 percent from Dec. 15 to Jan. 15 but averaged 8 percent higher than they did a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

Price Waterhouse Co., in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, alleging that the corporation's 1973 and 1974 annual reports were "false and misleading" in several particulars.

A black and white mutt apparently lost, obviously hungry and shivering with cold turned up at City Hall yesterday and ran into the president and executive vice president of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

Speziale ruled today in Superior Court that the identification of a fingerprint found on the screen door of Barbara Gibbons's cottage the day after she was murdered met two of the three criteria needed to win a new trial for her 20-year-old son, Peter Reilly.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 The White House said today that President Ford's campaign committee would pay part of the salary of the new Presidential counselor, Rogers C.B. Morton, if the Federal Election Commission rules that Mr. Morton's salary is covered by campaign spending limits.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the world's largest investor-owned company, reported yesterday almost no change in its earnings for 1975 despite a 10.6 percent increase in operating revenues. Earnings per share were down due to an increase in shares outstanding since the end of 1974.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 4 Cambodia today scheduled nationwide elections in six weeks.
BOCA RATON, Fla., Feb. 4 (UPI) Jimmy Connors had to struggle to beat unseeded Peter Fleming in the second round of a $60,000 Independent Players Association tennis tournament today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4-Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, seeking support for the Administration's foreign policies, said today that the United States was more endangered by "our domestic divisions" than by overseas adversaries.

Margaret Seabury Thomson, who with her late husband, Dr. James Claude Thomson, served for many years as educational missionaries in China, died Tuesday in South Kent, Conn., at the home of a daughter, Mrs. Julius E. Waller. She was 86 years old.
HAVANA, Feb. 4 (UPI) Military intervention in Angola has caused more complaining against the Cuban Government than any issue in recent years, according to resident diplomats.

With unusually cold weather persisting across much of the country last week, supplies of distillate oil, used primarily for home heating, continued to drop according to a report yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. The decline for the week was the third in a row.
A take-over by the state of the city's entire water-supply system was proposed yesterday by the City Council President, Paul O'Dwyer, and the Nassau County Executive, Ralph G. Caso.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday that it had received nearly $600 million in 1975 from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation in connection with the liquidation of the Franklin National Bank, which failed in 1974.
Over at Philip Morris U.S.A., John T. Landry, executive vice president-marketing, thinks the company has a winner on its hands with Merit, the new low-tar highflavor cigarette.

WASHINGTON, Feb.4 (AP) Derrick Jackson hit a 17foot jump shot with 1 minute 10 seconds to play in overtime tonight to help Georgetown upset 12th-ranked St. John's, 74-73, in basketball. Two free throws sealed the 'Hoyas' 15th victory in 18 games.

There are some textbook bidding sequences that hardly ever seem to occur in real life. An example is shown in the diagram: North opens one diamond and later bid hearts twice, indicating six diamonds, five hearts, and a better than minimum hand. Although he has only 13 high-card points, the power of his diamond suit justifies the strong reverse sequence.
"I remember Freddy," said Rafael Trinidad, a third-grader at Public School 75 on the Upper West Side. "We used to play football together in the gym. Now he's just dead."
A city building inspector yesterday declared unsafe to live in the West Side building in which 10 people died in a fire earlier in the day.
LONDON, Feb. 4 Shirley MacLaine danced, sang and joked her way into the hearts of her audience and newspaper critics Monday night in a 70-minute show that opened at the London Palladium.

HARTFORD, Feb. 4 Gov. Ella T. Grasso today proposed a record $1.801 billion budget designed to provide a measure of relief to Connecticut's hardpressed business community and to hold the like against spending.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 4-Patricia Hearst, pale and worried-looking, spent the second anniversary of her kidnapping today listening to the prosecutor in her bank-robbery trial describe her as a willing participant in the holdup and her chief defense lawyer say she was "a prisoner of war for 20 months" who could never have had any intent to rob a bank.

Taking careful measure of the complex and often conflicting values of technology, the environment and world politics, Transportation Secretary Coleman reached yesterday a cautiously balanced decision on the Concorde one that establishes a limited test period for flights into the United States under carefully controlled conditions.

LITCHFIELD, Conn., Feb. 4 A Superior Court judge was told here today that for months before she was murdered, 51year-old Barbara Gibbons had been involved in a feud with a neighbor over charges that he had had sexual relations with her son, Peter Reilly.

AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 4 (AP) King Hussein of Jordan issued a decree today indefinitely postponing parliamentary elections that had been scheduled for March 23 because of the continued occupation of the West Bank by Israel.
PARIS, Feb. 4-An ambitious UNESCO project to eradicate illiteracy, begun a decade ago, has been a dismal failure, according to the organization's own report.

INNSBRUCK, Austria, Feb. 4 The 12th Winter Olympics were declared open today.

Few current domestic controversies are more suited than the abortion issue to try a Presidential candidate's capacity for straight talk; President Ford is the latest to fail that test. While avoiding Ronald Reagan's all-out regressive anti-abortion stand, he has joined several of the Democratic candidates in straddling the issue in hopes of creating an illusion of middle-of-the-road reasonableness.

Fridrik Olafsson, an Icelandic grandmaster, came through with a finishing spurt that carried him to a tie for first prize with Yugoslav grandmaster Ljubomir Ljubojevic in the 38th Hoogoven international tournament in Wijk-aan-Zee, the Netherlands.
Winter racing continued its losing streak at Aqueduct yesterday when the jockeys, after two races on an "uneven and unsafe" track, unanimously decided to sit out the rest of the nine-race card.
CICERO, Ill., Feb. 4 (AP) Smoke and fire bursting from a fourth floor room killed six persons and injured 23 early today at a recently built nursing home in this suburb west of Chicago.

PARIS, Feb. 4 The French Communist leader, Georges Marchais, opened his party's 22d congress today with an attack on the Soviet Union for "unjust and unjustifiable" acts of repression against Soviet citizens.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 With an unusual assist from the Senate Budget Committee, President Ford easily won today a Senate floor fight over his veto of a bill raising Federal price supports for milk.

NEWARK, Feb. 4 Governor Byrne announced today a $1.2 million contract toward construction at Liberty State Park in Jersey City of a harborside recreation site that will offer a spectacular view of the Statue of Liberty in time for the Bicentennial Fourth of July.

DETROIT, Feb. 4 Sales of new United States cars were up 27 percent in January over last year, but import sales slumped 21 percent, automobile industry figures showed today. Auto analysts said the sales gain was better than expected and noted that last year's domestic sales had the benefit of price rebate programs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 The Justice Department challenged today the Government rules restricting the films and sports events that can be shown on cable television and charged that if the rules had been developed by the broadcasters they would violate the antitrust laws.
The operators of the Hillcrest Nursing Home in Spring Valley N.Y., received conditional discharges yesterday on their conviction for Medicaid fraud.

The top executive of the American Medical Association said yesterday that the fivepart series on incompetent doctors and inept medical practices published in The New York Times last week "stated many things that need stating," but that some of the conclusions were "unjustified" by the evidence on which they relied.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 5 A retired army lieutenant has testified before a congressional investigatory committee that foreign-made submachine guns were purchased with funds of Argentina's Ministry of Social Welfare to arm a right-wing organization known as the Triple A.
LISBON, Feb. 5 The Socialists have rebuffed a quiet but insistent effort by the Portuguese Communist Party to ally with them for the coming legislative elections.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 Treasury Secretary William E. Simon today expressed optimism regarding New York City's finances and said there was a "reasonable prospect" that the city would repay its Federal loans.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UPI) Opponents of efforts to overturn the Supreme Court's liberal abortion rights decision argued today that Congress cannot stop abortion, merely limit it to the rich or create hazardous medical conditions.

Otto F. Rieg, who retired in 1967 as vice president in charge of the underwriting department of the Home Insurance Company, died Monday, apparently of a heart attack, while vacationing in Ocean Ridge, Fla. He was 73 years old and lived at 26-01 Warren Road in Fair Lawn, N.J.

Although summer seems far away, now is the time for those who would like to make a horseback pack trip in any of Wyoming's wilderness areas to start planning for the event.
Dr. Valentine A. Hofmann, a specialist in internal medicine, died Wednesday at his home, 155 East 76th Street. He was 60 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 The chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence called today for the appointment of a special prosecutor to investigate evidence of criminal activity by the Central Intelligence Agency and the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 The Comptroller of the Currency, James E. Smith, said today that the United States banking system was sound, but disclosed that there were 28 national banks in either critical or serious financial trouble.

Raymond A. Meany, who retired in 1965 as general plant supervisor in Brooklyn after 51 years with the New York Telephone Company, died Wednesday at his home at 18 Summit Road in Elizabeth, N.J. He was 76 years old.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 5 While Patricia Hearst was showing cool curiosity toward movies of herself as a bank robber, shown at her trial in Federal District Court here today, two of her former associates pleaded that she not sell them out to gain her own freedom.

The argument that process may be everything in television is getting new and solid support from an organization called Martha Stuart Communications. Miss Stuart has taken the standard commodity of "talking heads" and given it a fresh context, and she is proving it to be a still sturdy vessel for information. Her programs are called "Are You Listening?," and three of the half-hours have been seen on public television.
LISBON, Feb. 5 After 21 months of sterile convulsions, the Portuguese revolution has come to a pause and seems to be seeking its own identity.

The LaSalle String Quartet, an ensemble known especially for its performance of 20thcentury music, featured Witold Lutoslawski's Quartet (1964) in the concert it gave Wednesday night at Hunter College Playhouse.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 Chemical control of important insect pests is losing effectiveness and the loss will probably accelerate, according to a report released today by the National Academy of Sciences. The report was more than three years in the making.

The board of directors of the Health and Hospitals Corporations voted yesterday to go ahead with a plan it had tentatively approved two weeks ago to reduce the number of municipal hospitals from 18 to 14, thereby cutting $240 million from its budget by mid-1978.
