MOSCOW, Feb. 5-Aleksandr and Lyudmila Lunts have packed their books in suitcases. They have begun to say goodbye to friends. They are finally going to Israel.
A five-man committee of the New York Stock Exchange recommended yesterday a "major overhaul" of the specialist system.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) The Federal Election Commission decided today not to render an advisory opinion on whether Rogers C.B. Morton, a recently appointed White House counselor, can act as a political adviser to President Ford while on the public payroll.

The Anaconda Company, a major copper producer and fourth largest domestic aluminum producer, reported yesterday an estimated loss of $10.3 million for the fourth quarter in contrast to net income of $16.2 million, or 23 cents a share, after a tax credit of $2 million, or 9 cents a share in the year-ago period. Revenues fell 14.3 percent to $294.5 million from $343.8 million.
LEESBURG, Va., Feb. 5 (AP) Twenty-two-year-old Owen Brown, former University of Maryland basketball forward, died of an apparent heart attack last night while playing a pickup game with co-workers.

The proposal by City Council President Paul O'Dwyer and Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso that the state take over New York City's water-supply system and manage it on behalf of the broader southeastern region represents a potentially significant breakthrough in city-suburban relations.

Marquette, as expected of the second-ranked college basketball team in the nation, had an easy time in beating Manhattan College, 78-59, last night in the second game of a double-header at Madison Square Garden. Jerome Whitehead scored 22 points before a crowd of 18,131 to lead the Warriors to their 17th victory in 18 games.

Ted Curson, an imaginative, creative and warmly communicative trumpet and flugel-horn player who has done most of his performing in Europe in the last 10 years, appeared with his seven-piece group for three nights this week at the Tin Palace, Second Street at the Bowery, and will return there on Sunday evening.

CHICKASHA, Okla., Feb. 5 Senator Lloyd M. Bentsen Jr. of Texas, fighting desperately to avoid elimination from the Presidential sweepstakes, is throwing major resources into the campaign for Oklahoma's 37 delegates to the Democratic National Convention.

LONDON, Feb. 5 (AP) Dr. Kathleen B. Dietrich, pioneer in research and operating on "blue babies" those born with defective hearts died in Guy's Hospital here yesterday. She was 55 yeas old.

Potato futures prices rose sharply yesterday after a report that Belgium now had agreed to the landing of a ship from Maine loaded with potatoes. The May deilvery on the New York Mercantile Exchange closed at 16.05 cents a pound up from 15.70.
Stock prices dropped yesterday, registering their sharpest decline of 1976 on the heels of a prolonged advance that had carried the market to a 27month high.

MOSCOW, Feb. 5 (Reuters) Tatyana Lyudvinskaya, one of the few remaining "old Bolsheviks," has died here, Pravda, the Communist Party newspaper, reported today. She was 88 years old.
Rising fuel prices, costly strikes and proliferating fare discounts drove the nation's airlines into a near-record deficit last year, according to recently-released year-end statements.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 5 Rain has fallen on much of California during the last two days, breaking the worst drought to hit the state since 1904. But California farmers are counting losses from the drought that could run into many millions of dollars, and many now fear that a cold snap following the summer-like weather will add millions more to their losses.

For the 15th consecutive year, poodles are the most popular pure breed in America, according to registration figures kept by the American Kennel Club. In 1975, 139,750 poodles were listed of a total of 1,022,849 dogs representing 121 breeds.

GENEVA, Feb. 5-The International Narcotics Control Board has called on Mexican authorities to intensify their fight against the illicit drug trade because of the "large quantities" of heroin, cocaine and marijuana that are reaching the United States from Mexico.
A bill changing the name of part of United Nations Plaza to Zion Square was passed yesterday by the City Council Committee on Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs.
Evelyn Russell, a stage and screen actress, died Jan. 28 at her home in Sherman Oaks, Calif. She was 49 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 Liberal Democrats, in a dramatic comeback, defeated the Administration-backed natural-gas deregulation bill on the House floor today, making it unlikely that any such measure would emerge from Congress this year.

HOBOKEN, Feb. 5-A 100-year-old one-time tenement building here, basically sturdy but long empty and decaying, was undergoing a transformation today into what officials hope will be a trim 10-unit apartment dwelling, with the help of an unusual Federal, state and local financing program.
Commuters in the metropolitan area may have tough sledding getting to work this morning, according to the National Weather Service.

Six more food establishments were cited by the city Health Department Wednesday for failing an inspection. They are subject to being closed if violations of the health code are not corrected before a second inspection.

ROME, Feb. 5 (Reuters) Italy's Socialist Party decided today that it would not vote against a minority Christian Democratic Government proposed by the Premier-designate, Aldo Moro, thus clearing the way to the end of a month-old political crisis.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) The Federal Communications Commission ordered its staff today to go ahead with plans for a temporary permit procedure to take care of the avalanche of applications for Citizen's Band radio lcenses.

DETROIT, Feb. 5-When Derrick Wolf, a 26-year-old apprentice electrician at the Ford Motor Company's stamping plant, gets into a cranky mood, feels tired or has put in four straight days at his job, he often just stays home.

YONKERS, Feb. 5 Robert N. Rickles, former Air Resources Commissioner in New York City, announced his candidacy today for the Democratic nomination for the House of Representatives from the 23d Congressional District.

Moving to aid the victims of the earthquake in Guatemala and Honduras on Wednesday, a group of Latin America's friends here have established a special relief fund and appealed for donations to provide housing in the devastated areas.

DETROIT, Feb. 5 American auto plants plan to build 167,895 cars this week, off less than 1 percent from last week's 168,622, according to the trade paper Automotive News.
Recourse to arbitration as a rational way to resolve employer-employee disputes got two needed lifts in recent court decisions.

The Board of Estimate gave its reluctant approval yesterday to a contract providing for an $8.1 million increase in Group Health medical-insurance premiums paid by the city for its employees, their dependents and retired Civil Service workers.
Pan American World Airways Inc. reported yesterday a net loss for last year's fourth quarter of $33.2 million and a net loss for all 1975 of $46.1 million.

The second ranking official of the United States Environmental Protection Agency charged here yesterday that "United States Steel has compiled a record of environmental recalcitrance which is second to none." The charge was disputed immediately, at the same meeting, by the company's environmental affairs vice president.
Profit taking and fears that the Federal Reserve Board might soon tighten its monetary policy weakened prices yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UPI) Senator Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania, the Senate minority leader, is the focus of Federal investigations for allegedly receiving money from the Gulf Oil Corporation's $5 million domestic political fund, Senate and Justice Department sources said today.

Ralston-Purina, which has already delivered Freakies and Fruity Freakies to an eager young populace, has now developed Grins Smiles Giggles Laughs. This, too, is a presweetened ready-to-eat cereal. Its special benefit is that on each crunchy, round, corn-based piece are two eyes and a smiling mouth.

The New York Stock Exchange, citing the "recent heavy volume," yesterday ordered all trading floor brokers to report to work on Saturday to help expedite the comparison of buy and sell transactions on which there is some doubt.

Disclosure by the Federal Reserve System that the number of bank-holding companies on its "problem" list has jumped sharply in the past year, along with a comparable increase in banks under "special surveillance," raises serious concern about the adequacy and the basic concepts of banking regulation in the United States.

INNSBRUCK, Austria, Feb. 5 Austria and the Soviet Union won opening day gold medals as they were supposed to do in the Winter Olympics but three astonishing performances by Americans today produced two silver medals and an undreamed of sixth place.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 5 (AP) Joe Hassett scored 13 of his game-high 21 points in the second half tonight in leading Providence to a 76-67 basketball victory over Niagara.

The Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, expressing concern about climbing imports of men's and boys' clothing, announced yesterday a campaign for a nationwide boycott of such products made abroad.

Seymour R. Thaler, the former crusading State Senator who was about to take a seat on the state Supreme Court when his career was shattered in 1972 upon his conviction of conspiracy with two others to sell stolen securities, died early yesterday of a heart attack at the age of 56.

Hugo Wolf's "Italienisches Liederbuch" is the last of his song cycles, It is an extraordinary compendium of poetry, mostly about love, and subtly complex music. Its 46 songs make a perfectly timed program, but the collection is a difficult one to master from an interpretive standpoint, and if not a rarity, it isn't exactly a staple in our concert life, either.
Robert C. (Sonny) Carson and five other defendants were acquitted yesterday of intentionally killing a 34-year-old Brooklyn man, but the jury continued to deliberate on a second murder charge.

Nearly all 78 members of Northern Ireland's Constitutional Convention have returned to Stormont to resume deliberations on the future of the strife-wracked province, thus providing practically the only cause for hope in the Ulster cockpit. Even the majority United Ulster Unionist Coalition agreed to prompt resumption of private negotiations between the parties; and the opening session was devoid of Protestant-Catholic acrimony.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 5 Edward W. Cook, chairman of Cook Industries Inc., a leading concern in the grain export trade, appeared before a Federal grand jury here today as an investigation of his company appeared to be approaching a decisive stage.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, which has already admitted having paid at least $22 million in bribes overseas, yesterday named a four-man committee of outside directors to "supervise and audit an investigation of commissions and payments on sales contracts."

WASHNGTON, Feb. 5 Eugene J. McCarthy announced today that he had selected William Clay Ford as his running mate on the independent thirdparty ticket with which he plans to challenge the Republican and Democratic Presidential nominees in the fall.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) Federal District Judge John J. Sirica, who gained national re cognition for his dogged pursuit of the truth in Watergate, suffered a massive heart attack today. His condition was critical.

ROME, Feb. 5 Representatives from 74 countries reached agreement here today on the terms for the creation of an International Fund for Agricultural Development to help poor countries increase their food production with low-interest loans.

Undefeated Duane Bobick will continue his cautious advance to a possible shot at the heavyweight championship tonight in the feature event of a boxing card that contains four 10-round fights at Madison Square Garden.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 (AP) The state should scrap its present state-aid formula and return to a formula based on the taxable wealth of school districts, the State School Boards Association said today.

For families that want to start thinking about what to do this summer, the Walden School, 1 West 88th Street, will hold a free get-together called Summer Camping '76 on March 1 from 6 to 9 P.M. in the school auditorium. UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb. 11 While the smallest home crowd of the season at the Nassau Coliseum searched for ways to keep themselves amused, the Nets struggled to a 120-110 American Basketball Association victory over the Spirits of St. Louis tonight.

Mother M. Brendan, assistant general of the Carmelite Sisters for the Aged and Infirm, operating nursing homes in this area, died Monday at the Motherhouse of the Carmelite Sisters at Avila in Germantown, N.Y.
NEWARK, Feb. 11 A 78year-old bank guard and one of three bank robbers were killed today in a shootout at the Carteret Savings and Loans Association here.

LONDON, Feb. 11 (AP) Charlie Naughton, one of the two surviving members of the Crazy Gang, a group of slapstick comedians who played for years at the London Palladium, died today. He was 89 years old.

LISBON, Feb. 11 The Portuguese Government announced today a suspension of its agreement with the three Angolan nationalist factions recognizing all three as legitimate representatives of the people of Angola.
BUFFALO, Feb. 11 A new law permitting statewide voter registration by mail was declared unconstitutional today by a justice in State Supreme Court here.

CONCORD, N.H., Feb. 11 As the day of decision nears, the confusion over who is ahead in the cluttered Democratic Presidential primary election in New Hampshire seems to most observers to be clearing a bit.
COLLEGE PARK, Md., Feb. 11 (A) North Carolina defeated Maryland, 81-69, tonight in a game between two of the nation's top-ranked basketball teams.

QUITO, Ecuador, Wednesday, Feb. 11 (Reuters) At least 60 people were believed to have been buried in a landslide tonight in the Pacific port of Esmeraldas in northern Ecuador. Five bodies were recovered before darkness stopped rescue work.
Warner Communications Inc. announced yesterday that it had decided to write down its inter est in the National Kinney Corporatiton by approximately $41 million to a total of $12 million.

Technological decisions about safety precautions at nuclear power plants are too crucial and too complex to be reached through angry public exchanges or attempts to engender panic. When equally authoritative voices shout totally opposite assessments about the safety measures built into the Indian Point No. 2 power plant on the Hudson River, or any of the rest of the nation's 56 licensed reactors, the public has every right to be confused, annoyed and concerned.
TRENTON, Feb. 11 (AP) Governor Byrne said today that he was confident that defense lawyers would not be able to frustrate his "90 days to trial" program if it was put into practice in New Jersey.

HILLSBORO, Va. No one around here brags about it, but this town is probably the richest in the United States comparatively. It's not that the people themselves are rich, for there are poor people here and no one in town could be classified as wealthy. But the town has enough in its till to distribute about $100 to every man, woman, and child if it were so inclined which it isn't.

By an overwhelming vote at their annual meeting in Los Angeles yesterday, member stations of the Public Broadcasting Service have approved a proposal to interconnect the 252 stations by means of Westar, Western Union communication satellite, at a capital cost of $38.4 million.
Viktor Tretyakov is not only a violinist of major stature but a man of steady nerves as well. He displayed both qualities during his recital at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night.

THE HAGUE, Feb. 11-Acting with caution and reluctance, the Netherlands has begun an investigation of allegations that Prince Bernhard accepted $1.1 million from the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation for help in selling planes to the Dutch Government.
ROME, Feb. 11 (Reuters) Prime Minister Aldo Moro tonight announced the formation of his fifth Government, which is seen here as a stop-gap solution to Italy's five-week-old political crisis.

COSHOCTON, Ohio, Feb. 11 (UPI) Cleon Dobson, who entertained thousands of visitors each year as Ohio's most famous blacksmith and the star attraction of the canal town of Roscoe, died Monday. He was 87 years old.

On the broader policy issue, the once-shining promise of nuclear power has grown so tarnished that realistic planning for this country's future energy needs must seek alternate fuels for generation of electricity.
The policy of the American Contract Bridge League is to schedule one of its three national championships each year on the East Coast, one in the West and one in a central state.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 11 (AP) Cesar Chavez, leader of the United Farm Workers, frustrated at the suspension of California's farm labor elections, called today for a new boycott against selected fruit growers.
The Knicks acted and played like "copy cats" last night in a National Basketball Association game against the Milwaukee Bucks at Madison Square Garden.

INNSBRUCK, Austria, Feb. 11 If anyone had told Rosi Mittermaier as recently as two weeks ago that she would win two gold medals and possibly three in the Winter Olympics, she would have disregarded the notion as a crazy dream.
MADISON, Wis., Feb. 11 (UPI) The State Senate defied the national and state Democratic parties tonight and refused to revise Wisconsin's Presidential primary.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 Although the "abortion issue" could hurt several Presidential aspirants, and may have helped former Georgia Gov. Jimmy Carter to his initial victory in Iowa Democratic caucuses, it is a peculiarly personal and persistent problem for Indiana Senator Birch Bayh.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation's chairman and at least one other top official are expected to step down "very soon" because of the scandal involving millions in payoffs for plane sales abroad, Government and industry souces said yesterday.

A lawyer who was denied a partnership in one of the country's major law firms has filed suit in Federal Court here charging that he was discriminated against because he is a Catholic and of Italian ancestry.

A $4,260 grand piano ordered by the Board of Education for a new high school in Brooklyn has struck a sour note with Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, who is balking at paying the bill.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 The Village Voice, a weekly newspaper in New York, today published 21 pages of excerpts from what it said was the text of the still-secret report of the House Select Committee on Intelligence.

Wheat futures prices rose yesterday on continued reports that the new winter wheat needed moisture to survive in some areas and that high winds had blown away cover for the struggling plantings in some areas. Governor Carey gave strong backing yesterday to the threeday Second World Conference on Soviet Jewry that opens in Brussels next Tuesday. Like the first conference there in 1971, it will press for greater freedom for Jews and for exit visas to those wishing to emigrate to Israel.
Martin Santini Sr., who retired in 1964 as president of the 7 Santini Brothers moving and storage company, died Monday at St. Barnabas Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 The House Select Committee on Intelligence prepared to go out of business at midnight tonight after what most of its members and staff have seen as nearly a year of frustration in its efforts to peer into the works of the dozen or so agencies that make up the Federal intelligence community.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 The Central Intelligence Agency announced today that it would cease recruiting agents among reporters for American news organizations or American clergymen and missionaries.

The American Express Company, when subpoenaed to provide financial information concerning its individual cardholders, releases the data without notifying the persons concerned, company officials testified yesterday.

"Rumania came in yesterday," Frank Braynard said at lunch. "The Mircea, a sister ship of the Eagle, built in 1936 in Hamburg, a three-masted bark of 265 feet. Her figurehead is a wooden statue of Mircea the Great, the Prince who saved Rumania's independence from Hungary, Turkey and Poland in Fourteen Hundred and Something when Rumania's name was Walachia. NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 11 (UPI) A Federal judge today declared a mistrial for the last defendant in the sponge-rubber plant arson trial because the jury could not reach a verdict.

William T. Seawell, chairman of Pan American World Airways, said yesterday that he hoped that $175 million of added expenses his company estimates it faces this year would be covered by additional revenues from increased traffic and an expected fare increase on North Atlantic business. He said he believed "the fare increase will work out at 6 percent."

Cigarette smoking has increased substantially among teen-age girls in the last six years, with 27 percent of girls 13 through 17 years old now smoking and 4 in 10 smokers using at least one pack a day, according to the findings of a survey conducted for the American Cancer Society.

In the science fiction world of "Star Trek," earthly divisions are a thing of the past. But promoters of the cult that has enveloped the television series, who live in the world of competition, seem to be having some trouble living up to the brotherhood ideal that the program fosters.
KANSAS CITY, Kan., Feb. 11 The Republican National Convention apparently will stay in Kansas City despite a recent squabble over the number of hotel rooms allotted to the party.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 11 Prime Minister Rashid Karami said today that Lebanon would continue to have a Christian President as part of the political changes in an agreement reached to end the ChristianMoslem crisis that took thousands of lives in nine months of fighting.

Senator Birch Bayh took his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination to the edge of Kennedy International Airport yesterday where he promised Rosedale homeowners that he would press for legislation to bar the Concorde supersonic jet from landing in this country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 In 1919, Federal District Judge Walter Evans of Kentucky paid his income tax under protest. Then he sued the tax collector. The tax, he argued, violated his constitutional right as a Federal judge not to have his salary "diminished."

TRENTON, Feb. 11-Governor Byrne said today that the state was preparing to relax air-pollution emission standards for certain areas of South Jersey to permit industries and power companies to burn fuels with higher sulfur content.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 Representative Ken Hechler started today a drive to end the Congressional franking privilege, saying that the practice, which antedates the founding of the Republic, has degenerated into a tool for incumbent legislators to dispense re-election campaign propaganda.

Sam Rivers, who is appearing through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, plays some of the longest tenor saxophone solos imaginable. He began his first set Tuesday evening with a 35-minute workout that would have left most younger saxophonists exhausted; then he performed on the flute and soprano saxophone for another half hour.
HARTFORD, Feb. 11 (AP) Gov. Ella T. Grasso, saying "wall-to-wall gambling" is a distinct possibility in Connecticut, called today for a two-part commission to oversee gambling in the state.
ROME, Feb. 11 (AP) The Vatican today formally rejected a condemnation of Zionism and a call for Arab control of Jerusalem approved at a Christian-Moslem conference held in Tripoli, Libya, last week.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12-The narrowly defined money supply spurted upward by $2 billion to $296.5 billion in the week ended Feb. 4, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and on the over-thecounter market were moderately higher yesterday in quiet, semi-holiday trading.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 17 Several hundred students stormed the British High Commission and the United States Embassy here today, smashing windows, wrecking cars and causing thousands of dollars in damage.
Every expert knows in theory, but does not always remember in practice, that in team play one can never afford to relax. Or hardly ever, as Captain Corcoran of H.M.S. Pinafore would have said.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 The Democratic and Republican leaders of the Legislature agreed with Governor Carey today to try to enact the New York State budget ahead of the March 31 deadline as a symbol of the state's worthiness for credit and an effort to persuade the financial community to lend the state the $4 billion it must borrow after April 1.

The wisdom of continuing work on the subway line to connect Manhattan and Queens through the 63d Street tunnel under the East River was questioned yesterday at hearings on Mayor Beame's proposed $1.466 billion capital budget for the fiscal year beginning next July 1.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 (AP) Mayor Richard J. Daley, struggling to end a court freeze on $150.8 million in Federal revenue sharing funds, announced today that Chicago will hire about 400 police officers under race and sex quotas established in a Jan. 5 court order.

LONDON, Feb. 17 In an apparent bid for broader public acceptance, the small British Communist Party has published some criticism of the Soviet Union and called for the achievement of "Socialism in Britain" by democratic means.
NEWARK, Feb. 17 A group of eighth graders learned today that Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson had once been offered a bribe, but issued a collective sigh of relief when he told them he had turned it down.

Because the Supreme Court has ruled that the Federal Election Commission was appointed by an unconstitutional method, the commission will go out of existence on March 1 unless Congress intervenes. It is probable that Congress will renew the commission. The pressure of public opinion in the wake of the Watergate scandal as well as the financial self-interest of the major parties and Presidential candidates seeking continued Federal subsidies make renewal a near-certainty.

UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb. 17 John Davidson, a big anchor in the New York Ranger net tonight, steadied his teammates through a storm of first-period shots and led the Rangers to a 3-1 victory over the New York Islanders.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 President Ford announced tonight the most sweeping reform and reorganization of the United States intelligence agen- cies since 1947.
The Industrial Credit Bank, wholly owned by the Iranian Government, has received a $50 million loan from a syndicate of 20 banks led by Kuhn, Loeb Company, the investment concern announced yesterday.

GARDEN TIME Although Moss Hart's play "The Climate of Eden" ran for only 20 performances on Broadway in 1952, it was a strangely haunting drama, centering on a close-knit, free-thinking family in a jungle setting. The play, which Mr. Hart directed and adapted from a novel by Edgar Mittelholzer, had a cast headed by John Cromwell, Penelope Munday and Isobel Elsom and also included a young Rosemary Harris.

The cost of feeding a family of four in New York City dropped 0.4 percent last week, the average cost of the 38 items in the market basket priced by the City Department of Consumer Affairs totaling $71.9l, 32 cents les than the week before.
On one of my early visits to BaskinRobbins, I overheard two kindergarten-age boys deciding what to order. "I'm having green. What flavor do you want?" asked the first.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17 The American Bar Association, bitterly divided and acting under pressure of law suits, moved today to allow, for the first time, limited advertising by lawyers of their services and their fees.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 17 (AP) Gov. Edwin W. Edwards said today the he had accepted campaign contributions from corporations, knowing that businesses could not legally make them under state law.

Fortified with new patents, the Zenith Radio Corporation may be preparin for the introduction of a radically different line of color television sets next fall.

SAN FRANC1SCO, Feb. 17 Jerry Brown, the 37-year-old Governor of California, is often compared to the young Jack Kennedy, but outside of his good looks, his Roman Catholicism, and the same sort of vague aloofness, it is a poor analogy.

HONG KONG, Feb. 17 In one of the sharpest attacks yet on alleged rightists, China's official daily newspaper, charged today that unnamed "capitalist roaders within the party" had distorted an important instruction from Chairman Mao Tse-tung last year and instead emphasized a call for unity, stability and economic growth.
Marjorie Muir Worthington, author, died yesterday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. She was 77 years old.

Finger face painting is out. Brushes, crayons, gadgets are in. After all, Leonardo didn't paint the Mona Lisa with his fingers. Professional make-up artists are depending more and more on their skill with tools and passing on their tricks to customers.

For more than a year, the leaders of Turkey and the Turkish Cypriot community have assured the world that they have no intention of retaining control indefinitely of the 40 percent of Cyprus seized by the Turkish Army in August of 1974. Whenever the two Cyprus communities have tried to negotiate about the island's political future, however, the Turkish side has refused to put any specific territorial proposals on the table.

The scene at Carnegie Hall on Monday night resembled nomination night of a political convention except that it is hard to think of a candidate these days who can churn up the kind of adoring frenzy that greeted Mstislay Rostropovich's playing of the Dvorak Cello concerto with the Cleveland Orchestra. He undoubtedly could have carried by acclamation whatever precinct Carnegie Hall lies in.

The Nedick's people say that the northwest corner of 34th Street and Broadway is the busiest in the world. Their flagship store sits on that corner, serving hot dogs and orange drinks et al. to 8,000 people a day. Another company's flagship store, Macy's, stands next door, bringing Nedick's the customers.

One hundred and twenty-seven owners and operators of housing developments and other large properties in the New York metropolitan area have charged 11 major oil companies with conspiring to keep oil supplies low and prices high in violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act.
A Supreme Court jury in the Bronx has awarded a total of $1.725 million in damages in a negligence suit that could have been settled out of court for $300,000.
Direct study of the deep sea floor from manned, deep-diving submersibles, now under way in the Cayman Trough of the Caribbean, is opening a new chapter in exploration of the earth's surface.
Target Group Index, a syndicated magazine audience research service, will include ZIP code area demographic information in its fourth annual study due this spring.
The New York Mets conceded yesterday it was doubtful that Mike Vail would recover from his foot injury and open the baseball season in right field on April 8.

A group of black Democratic officials declared yesterday that Daniel P. Moynihan, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, was unacceptable to them as a possible Democratic candidate for the United States Senate from New York.

LITCHFIELD, Conn., Feb. 17 Peter Reilly was "barinwashed" by the state police when he confessed to killing his mother two and a half years ago, a psychiatrist testified today as hearings on the youth's petition for a new murder trial resumed.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 17 Patricia Hearst testified in detail today about the bank robbery for which she is on trial and also told the jury of having been forced into sexual intercourse by two members of the revolutionary band that had kidnapped her.

MIAMI, Feb. 17 (AP) Gay Jitterbug ran away from previously unbeaten Elocutionist and easily withstood a late charge by a 22-to-1 shot today to win the featured $15,000 race by six lengths at Hialeah Park race track.
THE HAGUE, Feb, 17?In the world of multinational corporate dealings, Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands is known as a master public-relations man.
PARIS, Feb. 17 France today recognized the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola as the legitimate government of that former Portuguese colony.

GENEVA, Feb. 17 The United States and the Soviet Union called today on the 20-nation Disarmament Conference to complete this year the draft of an international convention to outlaw all attempts to manipulate th weather or modify the environment for military of other hostile purposes.

An estimated total of 15,000 garment workers were laid off yesterday when contractors whose shops do the sewing and some cutting of dresses balked at paying the new wage rates negotiated by dress jobbers and the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

This morning a group of students from the Chelsea Vocational High School will take a subway to Brooklyn, find their way to the austere main office of the New York City Transit Authority and present officials there with a check for $1,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 Representative Morris K. Udall had been fielding questions from students at Memorial High School in Manchester, N.H., for nearly an hour the other day when a curlyhaired young man stood up in the rear of the school gymnasium and, with a brash ring to his voice, asked, "What makes you think you're a better candidate for President when all your answers are like everybody else's?"

A three-drug combination treatment after surgery for breast cancer has dramatically reduced recurrence of cancer among patients who face a high risk of suffering a relapse, according to preliminary findings reported this week by Italian researchers.
LINCOLN, Neb. (UPI) Epoxy and other products make home appliance repairs a cinch for many people, but there are hidden dangers.
Floyd E. Anderson, a former State Supreme Court Justice and father of Warren M. Anderson, the Senate majority leader, died yesterday at a nursing home in Binghamton, N.Y. He was 85 years old.
Since 1960, an area along the San Andreas Fault 40 miles north of Los Angeles has risen some 10 inches, according to the United States Geological Survey.

TRENTON, Feb. 17 Fortyfive cases of trichinosis were reported in New Jersey last year, and state health officials said today that they probably resulted from the grinding up of pork in hamburger by some meat markets.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 17 "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest," the filmed version of Ken Kesey's novel about one man's battle for sanity in a mental institution, received today nine Academy Award nominations, the most for any new film of 1975.

CARABEDELLA, Venezuela, Feb. 17 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger today offered Latin America a six-point plan of United States cooperation in solving economic and other problems and he called on the countries involved to "get down to serious business" in discussing it.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) Senator Hugh Scott, Republican of Pennsylvania, said be had "no knowledge" that a Tenneco Inc. executive gave $2,000 in 1972 to buy tickets to a dinner honoring Mr. Scott.
WASHINGTON, Feb, 17 President Ford, in a nationally televised news conference, said tonight that Ronald Reagan was too conservative to be elected President.

In its report on the City University's five-year experience with open admissions, the Women's City Club has underscored two closely related factors affecting the future of that policy: The commitment to admit all high school graduates has been fundamentally sound, but the standards required for high school graduation are seriously inadequate.

KEENE, N.H., Feb. 17 When Representative Morris K. Udall surveys the political landscape these days, he says, "it all seems to be coming together," but he is well aware that appearances can be cruelly deceptive.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 17 Venezuela's Oil Minister said today that his nation's top delegate at the Petroleum Exporting Countries would have to resign to defend himself against charges of accepting a bribe from the Occidental Petroleum Company of Los Angeles.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 17 Albert F. Bender Jr., chairman of the United Nations Joint Inspection Unit, died yesterday in Geneva at the age of 61.

Somewhere south of Wards Island, spending the winter on the East River, are a lot of canvasback ducks. Somewhere in Central Park, but usually near Fifth Avenue because they seem to like the East Side better, are wild rabbits. There are foxes in Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx, pheasants along the Belt Parkway in Brooklyn, and muskrats all over Staten Island. Somewhere in the city there may even be a wild deer.

DETROIT, Feb. 17 The Chrysler Corporation, which has been seeking to bid itself of losing operations, confirmed today that it was negotating with the Fedders Corporation to self its Airtemp division which makes air conditioners and heating systems.

Many of the same characters, places and fantasies recur in General Westmoreland's autobiography and Jack Valenti's memoir of President Lyndon B. Johnson. Both principals got stuck in the Big Muddy, neither quite knew what went wrong to the very end of their public careers, and their stories add small and self-revealing footnotes to the history of the Vietnam War and its political and military rationale.

TOKYO Feb. 17 Two managing directors of the mam- moth Marubeni Trading Company resigned today after they and two other senior executives of the company took a congue- lashing in Parliament for their alleged part in the Lockheed scandal here but sleadfastly pleaded ignorance of bribery.

EAST BRUNSWICK, Feb. 17 About 50 legislators and their aides attended a five-hour briefing on possible tax proposals to ease the state's fiscal plight, but emerged no closer to a consensus on what action to take.

The Knicks lost to the Golden State Warriors, 10496, last night at Madison Square Garden and the script was the same as in so many of their previous 29 losses this National Basketball Association season.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 Governor Carey, in a move to spur the state's lagging economy, asked the Legislature today to delay indefinitely the implementation of major parts of the State Environmental Quality Review Act, which he signed with praise seven months ago.

A three-drug combination treatment after surgery for breast cancer has dramatically reduced recurrence of cancer among patients who face a high risk of suffering a relapse, according to preliminary findings reported this week by Italian researchers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UPI) Representative Otis Pike, chairman of the House intelligence committee, criticized the controls that President Ford announced for intelligence operations today as unlikely to curb abuses because only the executive branch will know what is going on.

A new testing technique designed to compensate for the alleged "cultural bias" of standard I.Q. tests has been developed by Dr. Jane R. Mercer, chairman of the sociology department of the University of California at Riverside.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) Relief organizations in Guatamala are being sent "a tremendous load of useless material" by well-meaning Americans, Representative Ken Hechler said today after a weekend visit to the Central American country, which was hit by an earthquake Feb. 4.

GRINNELL, Iowa A black admissions program instituted at Grinnell College after black students took over the library in 1971 has been invalidated by the faculty in the belief that it is unconstitutional.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 17 The executive council of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. gave a generally friendly welcome today to the new Secreatry of Labor, W.J. Usery Jr., but George Meany said that the federation no longer had any working relationship with President Ford and the White House.

The United States Steel Corporation joined other steelmakers yesterday in giving customers "incentives in the prices they pay for steel products used in the manufacture of cans for beer and carbonated beverages. The action will have the effect of reducing prices for the steel.

BETHPAGE, L.I., Feb. 17 The Government of Iran is reported to have decided not to order any more of the F-14 fighter planes from the Grumman Corporation beyond the 80 planes currently being produced for the Iranian Imperial Air Force.

DES PLAINES, Ill., Feb. 17 (UPI) UOP Inc. announced today that it and another creditor were pulling out of an arrangemnet to finance and manage the refinery at Come-byChance, Newfoundland, which UOP built for the New York Oil executive, John M. Shaheen.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 The Government agency charged with regulating savings and loan associations disclosed today that 63 institutions are now carried on its so-called problem list, compared with 51 at the end of 1974.

The official car of City Council President Paul O'Dwyer was reported stolen yesterday morning after his police bodyguard-driver found it missing from where he had parked it near Mr. O'Dwyer's West Side residence.

LONDON, Feb. 17 Just past midnight on Sunday, Feb. 1, four British mercenaries were returning to their Angola headquarters. A 60-millimeter rocket flew past their Land-Rover.

AMAGANSETT, L.I. Bill Lusty, one of a small band of eeling enthusiasts hereabouts, was speaking before a blazing fire in the warmth of his comfortable home here. This is eel country, and some of the best hauls come from Three Mile Harbor a few miles distant.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 17 Unconcerned by his world heavyweight championship defense against Jean-Pierre Coopman here Friday night, Muhammad Ali forecast today an exhibition against a Sumo wrestler in Tokyo, a July 4 title bout with Ken Norton in Pontiac, Mich., and other stops this year in Costa Rica, Germany and the Sudan.
The temperature climbed to 67 degrees here yesterday, making it the warmest Feb. 17 since 1891.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 The Ford Administration has broken off talks with India on the resumption of economic aid to indicate displeasure with India's policies toward the United States, according to State Department officials.

YONKERS, Feb. 17 The city of Yonkers, saved over the weekend from its fourth default deadline in three months, moved today toward the longterm financing that state officials indicated was the city's only hope.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Operations abandoned today its efforts to obtain the names of American and foreign journalists who have cooperated with the Central Intelligence Agency, saying that their identities were not crucial to the success of its investigation of the Federal intelligence agencies.
KASHGAR, China The ancient city of Kashgar, once the principal oasis stop on the Old Silk Road from China to the Roman Empire, has revived its 2,000-year-old art of carpet weaving.

Monday was George Washington's official birthday, and the Long Island Chamber Ensemble of New York used its concert in Alice Tully Hall that night to honor Roy Harris. The occasion was appropriate because he is one of the most American of composers and he had celebrated his 78th birthday Feb. 12.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 17 Attorney General Bill Baxley has reopened an investigation of the bombing of Birmingham's 16th Street Baptist Church in 1963 in which four young black girls were killed. He has learned the names of nine men that a former F.B.I. informer says were involved in the bombing, a Birmingham newspaper reported today.

Paul Russo, an auto race driver for 33 years and a veteran of 15 Indianapolis 500's, died in his sleep Sunday night in Daytona Beach, Fla. Mr. Russo, a resident of Indianapolis, was in Daytona for Sunday's 500-mile stock-car race. He was 62 years old.
BOSTON, Feb. 17 (UPI) Two teen-agers were arrested tonight in the second consecutive night of minor disturbances by small groups of youths in Boston's Charlestown section.
American wine drinkers have an ambivalent approach to German wines. On the one hand, we consume an ocean of Blue Nun and have made it one of the few successful brand names in the wine world.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 Following are the text of President Ford's message to Congress outlining proposed changes in the structure and authority of the intelligence community and excerpts from his executive order, effective immediately, placing new restrictions on intelligence activities and establishing a new oversight apparatus.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 The leading Congressional critic of the Federal Election Commission reversed himself today and proposed legislation to continue the agency in operation.

Sam Chatmon is a black singer and guitarist whose repertory includes folk songs that predate the blues. Few of his surviving contemporaries retain a fraction of their musical abilities, but the 77-year-old Mr. Chatmon is an exception. His touch and time are still sure and his sweet, high tenor, which sometimes takes on a cracked blues coloration and sometimes slides effortlessly into falsetto is unimpaired.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 18 Even in the slowest-to-recover metals and mining industry, the feeling is that 1976 will turn out to be a very good year. But along with the warm glow of anticipation that suffuses most businessmen comes the defensive chill: The only thing harder to do than to apologize for no profits is to explain away profits.

Plans for developing an "electronic newsroom" to serve the writers and editors of all the news, features and other editorial copy in The New York Times were announced yesterday by the newspaper and the Harris Corporation of Cleveland.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 18?The Phillips Petroleum Company, one of the first companies identified as having made illegal, contributions to the 1972 reelection campaign of President Richard M. Nixon, agreed today to significant administrative changes in settling a class action stockholders' suit.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 Herman Schwartz vigorously defended today the conduct of the state's Commission of Correction since it was restructured by Governor Carey last summer, as well as his own conduct as head of the agency.
OTTAWA, Feb. 18 The Canadian Government announced today that it would limit, increases in federal spending during the fiscal year beginning April 1 to 16 percent as part of its attack on inflation.
The Village Voice published yesterday a document that it said was another part of the still-secret report of the House Select Committee on Intelligence, The Associated Press reported.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 Ewald B. Nyquist, the State Education Commissioner, became the first member of the Governor's cabinet to break with Mr. Carey over the proposed State expense budget when he urged the Legislature today to override the governor's request for a $110 million cut in state aid to local school districts.

Maurizio Pollini, giving the impression he was out to prove something, devoted his piano recital last night in Carnegie Hall to Schubert and Beethoven. He did not spare himself. Every work on the program was packed with information as the computer boys say, and a good deal of concentration was demanded from pianist and audience.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Feb. 18 France and Somalia traded accusations in the Security Council today about shooting incidents in the area of the French East-African Territory of Afars and Issas. The incidents were touched off by the hijacking of a school bus carrying French children on Feb. 3.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UPI) The House Judiciary Committee killed Legislation today that would have banned the manufacture, sale, resale and importation of cheap, easily concealable handguns.

Dr. Benjamin Spector, protessor emeritus of anatomy and the history of medicine at Tufts University, died Tuesday in Long Beach (L.I.) Memorial Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived at 164 Albany Boulevard in Atlantic Beach.

Citing the statute of limitations, Federal officials concluded yesterday that the United States Attorney and the Internal Revenue Service were precluded from pursuing prosecution of any charges involving a $10,000 payment by the Gulf Oil Corporation to William J. Flanagan, the executive director of the New Jersey Turnpike.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 Assembly Democrats and Senate Republicans today reached agreement in principle on a stalled bill that could allow the resumption of work on eight publicly financed housing projects in New York City as early as Monday.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 18 Organized labor's top leaders have been making plans here this week to mount what they say will be the most effective political action effort in the history of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.

An indictment charging Herman Katz, who served as City Clerk for 16 years, with official misconduct was dropped last month in State Supreme Court after it was discovered that the Statute of Limitations prohibited prosecution, an examination of court records showed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 A simple, one-step process for converting wood alcohol to high-grade gasoline has been reported in a technical journal by scientists of Mobil Oil Corporation and its research subsidiary.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (Reuters) The head of the Citizens for Reagan Committee said today that it was "ludicrous" of President Ford to claim that Ronald Reagan was too conservative politically to win a national election.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 The Environmental Protection Agency ordered today an immediate ban on the production of virtually all pesticides containing mercury.
The sloop Clearwater has become a victim of the very environment she was commissioned to save seven years ago the Hudson River itself.

DETROIT, Feb. 18 The sound of Dan Maloney's stick, as he crashed it in anger against the wall, echoed in the lobby of Detroit's Olympia Stadium. Maloney had a grand seat in the penalty box tonight to watch the New York Islanders' deadly power play the best in the league produce the winning goal in New York's 5-3 victory over the Red Wings.

TRENTON, Feb. 18 State Attorney General William F. Hyland announced today the indictment of a third Passaic County Freeholder in an alleged scheme to get money from people and companies seeking to do business with the county.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 Interpol, the international police organization, has been warned by the United States that grain exporters in this country have defrauded foreign customers by about $120-million a year over the last five years.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 18 (AP) The Kentucky House voted today to rescind its 1972 ratification of the Equal Rights Amendment.
KANSAS CITY, Feb. 18 (UPI) Chuck Arnason scored his 15th goal of the season with 7:42 remaining in the game tonight to give the Kansas City Scouts a 3-3 tie with the Boston Bruins.

TORREMOLINOS, Spain, Feb. 17 The United States continued to dominate the 16th annual Costa del Sol International Tournament through 10 rounds in the Hotel Cervantes here. I hold the lead with 7 points and Larry Christiansen is following closely with 7.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UPI) The Senate approved today legislation freeing members of Congress from the payment of state income taxes in Maryland despite charges that the bill amounted to a "free ride."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UPI) A senate subcommittee has voted to provide more control over human experimentation conducted by the Defense Department, the Central Intelligence Agency and other Government researchers.

The United States yesterday seized a 24,000-ton freighter flying the Bahamian flag, the S.S. Pyramid Veteran, because the vessel arrived here last month with 112 pounds of cocaine hidden in her prow locker area.

A program "to make New York a boom town again through tax reductions, lower energy costs factory construction and putting more corporate know-how into city government was proposed yesterday by the Association for a Better New York.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) President Ford submitted to the Senate today a SpanishAmerican military cooperation treaty and said he envisioned integration of Spain "into the institutions of Europe and the North Atlantic defense system."

JAMESBURG, N.J., Feb. 18 Looking for a means of "exposure" and another vehicle for raising money, the Roman Catholic Diocese of Trenton announced yesterday a three-year contract with the Ladies Professional Golf Association during which the dioces will sponsor a tournament on the L.P.G.A. tour each year at Forsgate Country Club. This is believed to be the first time that any church organization has sponsored a tour golf tournament men's or women's.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 A Federal grand jury today charged 23 manufacturers of folding paperboard boxes, including the industry's three largest, with engaging in a criminal conspiracy to fix prices.

CONCORD, N.H., Feb. 18 Most of the time the rest of the country does not really care a whole lot about what New Hampshire's thinking or doing.
NEWARK, Feb. 18 (AP) A self-employed New York records salesman accused of participating in a payola conspiracy won a directed acquittal today from the judge in the case.
LONDON, Feb. 19 (AP) Britain, seven other Western European countries and Canada extended diplomatic recognition to the People's Republic of Angola today, but West Germany held back.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 The Senate passed today the most sweeping overhaul of the foreign military aid program in over 20 years, adding an amendment that would put an embargo on the shipment of American-made weapons to Chile.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 18 (UPI) Defense motions to drop 10 of 11 charges against William and Emily Harris, two members of the self-styled Symbionese Liberation Army, were rejected by a Superior Court judge.

Arbitration is an invaluable device for resolving disputes arising out of the interpretation of labor-management contracts, and nowhere more so than in the unionized civil service. LINCOLN, Neb., Feb. 18 (UPI) The Nebraska Educational Television Commission has filed suit to force the National Broadcasting Company to stop using the new N symbol that NBC developed as the key to a $750,000 corporate identity program.

James M. Gaines, a former vice president of NBC and a broadcasting executive in San Antonio, died Tuesday night at Northeast Baptist Hospital there after having suffered a stroke. He was 64 years old and lived in San Antonio.
Stanley W. Gregory, who retired in 1970 as controller of the Ford Foudation, died Monday at his home in Lake Worth Fla. He was 67 years old and had formerly lived in Southbury, Conn.
LITCHFIELD, Conn., Feb. 18 Hearings on Peter Reilly's bid for a new trial for the 1973 murder of his mother ended here this afternoon in quiet anticlimax after six weeks of contentious testimony.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 President Ford proposed legislation today that would make it a serious crime for Government employees to disclose the ways in which the Central Intelligence Agency and other Federal agencies collect and evaluate their information.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UPI) Housing starts fell for the third consecutive month in January, but the number of new building permits issued an indication of future homebuilding activity rose to the highest level in almost two years, the Commerce Department said today.

A suggestion by the Beame administration that two uncompleted public-school buildings in Brooklyn be put on the auction block was sharply criticized yesterday by community and Board of Education representatives.

Forecasts of rain over Kansas and Texas starting today led to a rush of profit taking in wheat futures contracts on the Chicago Board of Trade. March wheat was down almost the 20 cents-a-bushel limit during the session but it closed at $3.78 a bushel, off only 14 cents after lower prices led to some commercial buying.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 18 The shape of the conflict between the baseball players and the club owners was growing clearer as their representatives met in another of their itinerant bargaining sessions here today.
HONG KONG, Feb. 18 (UPI) The Chinese Communist Party newspaper Jenmin Jih Pao said today that "things are not going very well" for opponents of Chairman Mao Tsetung.

A nine-month-old harbor seal found stranded at Jones Beach State Park was moved yesterday to the Bronx Zoo suffering from dehydration, pneumonia and the bites of dogs that had attacked it as it lay beached at the shoreline.

LIMA, Peru, Feb. 18 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinget, arriving here today as part of a tour of six Latin-American countries, spoke approvingly of the nonalignment policy of the Peruvian left-wing military Government, but reminded his hosts that they were "part of the Western Hemisphere."
BOSTON, Feb. 18 Sargent Shriver said today that a number of Soviet Jews in whose behalf he had intervened have been given permission to leave the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 The Senate passed today the most sweeping overhaul of the foreign military aid program in over 20 years, adding an amendment that would put an embargo on the shipment of American-made weapons to Chile.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Feb. 18 Two daily newspapers have protested an order issued yesterday by Somerset County Judge Wilfred P. Diana that they not print any testimony or motions made outside the presence of the jury at a murder trial here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) Senator William Proxmire, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, says the Government should make public the names of all foreign officials who took payoffs from the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.

Buoyed by favorable economic news, prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market advanced yesterday in heavy trading.

Thomas V. Jones, one of the corporate chiefs in the United States who has withstood the disclosure of huge company payoffs, retained his No.1 position at the Northrop Corporation yesterday. A dividend increase by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company took Wall Street pleasantly by surprise yesterday, helping to lift both Stock prices and investor morale following three days of market decline.

The likelihood of a college president turning up as a pianist in an Alice Tully Hall concert is virtually nil, but on Tuesday night one did. TRENTON, Feb. 19 Amid growing confusion about public school financing, the New Jersey Supreme Court advanced today by three weeks the deadline it had given the State Legislature to find the $375 million needed to balance school budgets.
Ellen Greene first called attention to herself as a singer in predominantly homosexual cabarets. Then she was an actress, most recently in the Paul Mazursky film "Next Stop Greenwich Village."
ROME, Feb. 19 (UPI) Topseeded Arthur Ashe turned back a determined Stan Smith, 5-7, 6-4, 6-4, tonight and gained the semifinals of a $60,000 World Championship Tennis tournament.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 19 Calling lead additives in gasoline a health menace, California's Air Resources Board voted today to eliminate the major portion of lead additives in the state over a three-year period beginning Jan. 1.

LONDON, Feb. 19 Prime Minister Harold Wilson's Labor Government, conceding that the cost of Britain's ambitious social-welfare programs was crippling the economy, today announced vast cuts in its publicspending plans.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 19 A study to be published later this month by the Brookhaven National Laboratory warns of perils to people, the pine barrens and the resort industry if a multibillion-dollar cluster of nuclear energy plants were placed in Ocean County, N.J.

City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, who last week balked at paying a $4,260 bill for a grand piano for a high school in Brooklyn, has struck down another symbol of municipal luxury towel service in the judicial washrooms of the Queens courthouses in Kew Gardens and Jamaica.

Asserting that recent Supreme Court decisions have led to a substitution of anti-religious values for religious values in public education, the Roman Catholic Bishops of Pennsylvania called yesterday for educational reform that would permit religious teaching within public school curriculums.

William Cahn, the former Nassau County District Attorney, testified yesterday that after he was indicted he had tried to persuade an informant whom he had code-named "Sam Houston" to come to his defense.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 19 (UPI) James Farmer, a founder of the Congress of Racial Equality, said today that he was resigning from the group because of internal differences over the Angolan civil war.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 Assembly Democrats today disclosed a proposal aimed at increasing the benefits paid to the state's unemployed and to shoring up the rapidly dwindling state unemployment insurance fund. These two goals would be achieved by instituting a new system of determining employer contributions.
A judge has ruled here that a section of the Family Court Act is unconstitutional because it provides for granting counsel fees to a wife's lawyer but not to the husband's.

Gone are the days when Jacob Potofsky, head of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, could make a grand gesture by resigning from the board of the City Center of Music and Drama Inc. in 1952 because its own New York City Ballet planned to perform in "Franco Spain." The decibel count on ideological fervor is rather low at the City Center nowadays. Pin-stripe suits are more in evidence among its officers than union labels.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 19 The executive council of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. strongly defended food stamps today and accused the Agriculture Department of failing to administer the program in a way that would prevent fraud and cheating.
LONDON, Feb. 19 British officials are growing increasingly concerned that the success of Soviet-supported forces in Angola could lead to further wars of liberation engulfing all of southern Africa.

Carl Andre has been internationally known as a gifted and serious artist since the late 1950's. His reputation owes nothing to sensational publicity of the kind that for the moment surrounds it in London. It has been made, on the contrary, in tranquillity (and, initially, in isolation). Mr. Andre made the work he wanted to make. If people wanted to see it, so much the better. If not, he'd make it anyway.

Much of Anthony Newman's organ-playing in the first half of his recital at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night was the worst this listener has heard in years sloppy, smeared, poorly coordinated between manuals and pedals, rhythmically chaotic and so ineptly registered as to make the magnificent new organ sound ugly.

A Government official made public yesterday the results of a consultant's study concluding that the Ford Administration bill to ease airline regulation could lower fares and result in 18 million new passengers a year on 60 short-and mediumrange routes.

Starting March 1, American citizens, as well as Canadians and Mexicans, will be able for the first time to buy U.S.A. Rail passes for unlimited coachclass rides on Amtrak's 26,000mile national rail passenger system.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 Leaders of two statewide organizations of law enforcement officers urged the State Senate today not to confirm Governor Carey's apointment of Herman Schwartz as chairman of the State Commission of Correction, but several top-ranking lawyereducators held that he was highly qualified for the post.
The indictment of a major segment of the paperboard carton industry comes at a time when the industry has been passing through its worst slump in a decade.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 The Justice Department said today it would not prosecute Richard Helms for his role in a 1971 domestic burglary, but an official said that Congressional testimony of the former Director of Central Intelligence was being reviewed.

Anne Armstrong's husband, Tobin, held the Bible yesterday at her swearing-in as Ambassador to Britain. President Ford, looking at a beaming Betty Ford, said Mrs. Armstrong was an example of the kind of woman his wife "is always needling me" to appoint: "Whenever [Mrs. Armstrong] has done something, she has done a superb job."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 Vice President Rockefeller asserted today that Presidential candidates were campaigning on "personalities and promises" in the primary elections. "We are not having an informed debate on the grave issues that face present day America." he said.

In manner and style, William W. Scranton, President Ford's reported choice as chief United States Representative to the United Nations, will probably furnish the most striking contrast imaginable to his colorful predecessor. Yet there can be no doubt that the former Pennsylvania Governor, Congressman and aide to two Secretaries of State will defend the genuine interests of the United States as zealously as did Mr. Moynihan.
BRUSSELS, Feb. 19 An international conference on the plight of Soviet Jews ended tonight with a call on Moscow "to end the campaign of antiSemitism" and to allow free emigration of Jews to Israel.

LONDON, Feb. 18 It is a pity, in a way, that a piece of brick sculpture put together by the New York minimalist Carl Andre has achieved its greatest public notoriety on the eve of the bicentennial exhibition of the paintings of John Constable, as maximum a figure as there is in the rich history of English landscapes.
Robert J. McDermot, a member of the director's staff of the National Security Agency, died Wednesday evening at Nassau Hospital in Mineola, L.I. He was 48 years old and lived in Rockville, Md.

The City Record, which has been recording the city's official business daily since 1873, will eliminate its Saturday edition beginning in March, but will continue to print five days a week. The Municipal Service Administrator, John T. Carroll, said the new schedule would save the city $104,000 a year.
PARIS, Feb. 19 (AP) France has agreed to back credits of 340 million francs, or $77,3 million, to India for purchases of goods and services in France, the Finance Ministry announced today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 No democratic nation, once having liberalized the availability of abortion, has returned to more restrictive laws, according to a new study of abortion laws around the world.
TV Magic Ltd., a six-yearold company whose very existence depends on television commercials, is considering augmenting them with newspaper ads.

TRENTON, Feb. 19 Governor Byrne said today that the state might run out of transit subsidy money on March 1 and that this could close down commuter bus service in New Jersey and possibly curtail rail services.

The Lockheed Aircraft Cor poration believes that its pro posed $750 million contract to supply Canada with 18 Orion long range patrol aircraft has not been jeopardized by the re cent revelations that the com pany paid bribes to obtain foreign contracts.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 19 (AP) The Cleveland Cavaliers trounced the Portland Trail Blazers, 112-94 tonight for their seventh straight National Basketball Association victory.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 19 (AP) Tom Jenkins shot a five-under-par 66 today and took the first-round lead in the $185,000 Glen CampbellLos Angeles open. But the star of the day was 63-yearold Sam Snead.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 President Ford won another confrontation with Congress today as the Senate sustained his veto of a $6.2 billion measure aimed at creating jobs in state and local public-works programs.
Helen Powell Schauffler, who had been a community service worker for many years in New Rochelle, N.Y., died Wednesday in Portland, Ore., where she lived. She was 85 years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board warned Congress today that efforts to improve the job situation by a larger budget deficit, which would mean a more stimulative Government fiscal policy, could well backfire.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 The possibility was raised today that the virus that caused the greatest world epidemic of influenza in modern history the pandemic of 1918-19 may have returned.

BOSTON, Feb. 19 Until fairly recently, students of American political behavior tended to disparage the independent voter, calling him less alert and less politically sophisticated than Republicans and Democrats.

TRENTON, Feb. 19 Police dogs were used today to break up a disturbance by a splinter group of college students who scuffled with state troopers on the steps of the State House after pelting it with rocks and 2-by-4's and demanding to meet with Governor Byrne.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 19 (UPI) Richard M. Nixon flies to China tomorrow for a controversial visit labeled "strictly private" by the White House but denounced by a leading Democrat as an "outrage" meant to embarrass President Ford.
Foreign judges, who often give American athletes low scores in international meets, will now be identified by country, if a plan by the head man of gymnastics in this country succeeds.

The Government budget for social events given by the United States Mission to the United Nations has been supplemented for many years by private contributions. This special fund has been channeled to the mission by the United Nations Association of the United States of America, a private group of United Nations supporters.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) The House voted today to order its ethics committee to investigate the leak of its Select Committee on Intelligence's secret report and to determine whether to take action against Daniel Schorr, a CBS correspondent, fo his role in its publication.
EN GARDE! "The Count of Monte Cristo" immediately rings a bell with many people as a classic adventure brimming with action and intrigue. There was the old Alexandre Dumas novel.
Dr. Lawrence Kurzrok, former professor of gynecology and endocrinology at the Long Island College of Medicine, died Feb. 12 in Sarasota, Fla.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) President Ford asked Congress today to appropriate $25 million in earthquake relief funds for Guatemala.
The folding paperboard box-making industry generally expressed a sense of shock yesterday at Wednesday's indictment of 23 of its leading producers by a Federal grand jury in Chicago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 A private humanitarian organization headed by Leo Cherne, one of President Ford's appointees to a new committee that will investigate possible abuses of authority by the Central Intelligence Agency, reportedly received some $15,000 of C.I.A. funds in the mid-1960's that were channeled through a New York City philanthropic organization.
Safeway Stores Inc., the nation's largest grocery chain in terms of sales, achieved record sales and earnings in the quarter and annual periods ended Jan. 3.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 19 (AP) A member of the self-styled Symbionese Liberation Army, Russell Little, was found not guilty today on charges stemming from a gunfight with the Concord police, but jurors said that they were still deadlocked on similar charges against Joseph Remiro.

BONN, Feb. 19 (AP) West Germany, Austria and Japan today announced recognition of the Soviet-supported Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola as the legal government of the former Portuguese colony.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 19 The Syrian-imposed peace that is settling over Lebanon already contains hints of a firmness and political tidyness within both Lebanon and the Palestinian guerrilla movement that have been conspicuously absent in the last 10 months of near anarchy and civil war.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 19 Six days after the assassination of the head of state, Nigeria is riding a sea of strong emotions. There are waves of sorrow, and a strong undercurrent of anger.

United Air Lines Inc., which is still recovering from the after effects of a 16-day strike in December, and National Airlines Inc., which resumed service only on Jan. 6, after having been struck since Aug. 31, both reported losses for January.

LONDON, Feb. 19-Prime Minister Harold Wilson's Labor Government, conceding that the cost of Britain's ambitious social-welfare programs was crippling the economy, today announced vast cuts in its public-spending plans.
Bill Norton, the manager of the state-owned Cannon Mountain in New Hampshire, did what no ski area operator usually likes to do.
City officials reported yesterday that layoffs resulting from the fiscal crisis were having "devastating" effects on minority employment in government.

The Fordham Athletic Governing Board has recommended to the school administration that Hal Wissel not be retained as the basketball coach. Wissel has another season remaining on a two-year contract.

A member of Congress and two State Senators accused the Beame administration yesterday of catering to a small group of private landlords by writing long-term leases at exorbitant rents for city day care centers.

Since Chile's right-wing military Government took power in a coup two and a half years ago, it has received some $2 billion in foreign credits, despite extremely adverse economic problems, a compilation from World Bank sources shows.

So far as the New York school situation is concerned, the argument can certainly be made that any ironclad seniority rule is stultifying; but subjective personnel policies have too often been used as a cover for discriminatory practices and political favoritism.
SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 19 (UPI) Haroon Rahim routed Vitas Gerulaitis and Jimmy Connors defeated Brian Teacher in third-round action tonight in the national indoor open tennis championships.
LISBON, Feb. 19 Prime Minister Jos Pinheiro de Azevedo of Portugal flew to the Madeira Islands today to install a new governing junta, in a major move toward autonomy for the Atlantic archipelago.

Few people appreciate that a classical education has some advantages for a serious student of bridge. For the last two decades, it has been important to study the deeds of the Romans admittedly modern Romans. And Classical Greek has now entered the picture unexpectedly.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 19 Syrian mediators have begun talks here toward defining the status of the Palestinian guerrilla movement in Lebanon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 The Justice Department said today it would not prosecute Richard Helms for his role in a 1971 domestic burglary, but an official said that Congressional testimony of the former Director of Central Intelligence was being reviewed.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 19 Uninspired by what appears to be a mismatch, Muhammad Ali will defend the world heavyweight boxing title tomorrow night in a scheduled 15-round bout that will test the credibility of the challenger, Jean-Pierre Coopman of Belgium, as well as the resiliency of the champion.

The question after Wednesday night's Carl Ruggles centenary retrospective concert at Columbia's McMillin Theater is not so much whether Ruggles is as great a composer as his champions say he is, but whether a concert by the Performers' Committee for 20th-Century Music is a proper showcase for making such a judgment.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 18 As might be expected, the newspapers here are full of the Patty Hearst trial, particularly her sensational testimony about forced sex at the hands of Symbionese Liberation Army soldiers. Television news features frequent replays of the Hibernia bank robbery and Los Angeles shootout films.

The place to feel the pulse of the garment district is Dubrow's, which is a large cafeteria on Seventh Avenue and 38th Street. People from the garment district eat there, and when they do they talk about things that matter. What matters most right now is the dispute between the contractors and jobbers. No one in Dubrow's yesterday liked it.

BUFFALO, Feb. 19 (AP) Third-period goals by Rick Martin and Bill Hajt carried the Buffalo Sabres to a 3-1 National Hockey League victory over Atlanta tonight and extended the Flames' streak on the road without a victory to eight games.
A Federal appeals court declared yesterday that Civil Service seniority was not immune from legal challenge by women police officers who were dismissed in the city's fiscal crisis.

Business loans at leading New York City banks, a key indicator of credit demand from the private sector of the economy, declined again in the week ended Wednesday, extending a slump that has been under way for months.

Current trends that are depopulating families and narrowing judgments of children to measures of their intellects directly touch all American children. But a particular group is afflicted by all these pressures and one more besides exclusion. These are children born in the cellar of our society and systematically brought up to remain there.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 The Gulf Oil Corporation pleaded guilty in Pittsburgh today to four counts of a criminal indictment involving Federal energy regulations and was fined $20,000 by Judge Daniel Snyder in Federal District Court.

Mack Morriss, a top combat correspondent for the Army magazine Yank in both Europe and the Pacific during World War II, died of emphysema Wednesday in a Johnson City, Tenn., hospital. He was 56 years old.

Karen L. Bressler, a vice president, secretary, treasurer and a member of the board of directors of Karlin Productions Ltd., an independent motion picture producing company here, was married yesterday afternoon to Stephen Rosenberg, a member of and floor trader at the Commodity Exchange.

Two top officials of the Democratic state committee were dismissed yesterday and a third committee official resigned. All three are women and were among the first wom en to play major roles on the state committee.
Trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange set a record of 39.21 million shares yesterday as stock prices rose. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 15.67 points.

BOSTON, Feb. 19 Genetic specialists here to exchange views on the probable origins of the early Americans seem almost unanimous in their belief that, particularly in South America, these groups remained completely isolated from the rest of the world after the last Ice Age some 10,000 years ago.
MADRID, Feb. 15 Spain's lengthiest and most widespread strike movement in 40 years is now gradually slackening "but its effects on the labor force are expected to be profound.

A fine individual effort by Adrian Dantley, Notre Dame's 6-foot-5-inch all-America basketball candidate, foiled a hustling upset bid by Fordham last night in the second game of a doubleheader at Madison Square Garden.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 19 Patricia Hearst invoked the Fifth Amendment protection against self-incrimination 19 times this afternoon, including once when she said that to answer any questions whatever about her movements between September 1974 and her arrest here on Sept. 18, 1975, would possibly incriminate her.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI) The Justice Department today charged the Arab Information Center and its director, Amin Hilmy 2d, with having violated the Foreign Agents Registration Act in its propaganda efforts on behalf of the League of Arab States.

Johnny Bench, twice the National League's most valuable player, signed his 1976 contract with the Cincinnati Reds yesterday for a reported $200,000. That made the eight-time All-Star catcher the third man in baseball history to sign for $200,000 or more. Dick Allen with the White Sox and Henry Aaron with the Braves preceded Bench.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Feb. 19 An angry and boisterous Overflow crowd of 1,200 Nassau and Queens County residents vigorously protested tonight plans to permit the Concorde SST to use Kennedy International Airport.
UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb. 19 Nazareth of Brooklyn won the distance medley in 10 minutes 29.5 seconds tonight in the championship section of the Nassau County Relays at the Coliseum.
