DULUTH, Minn. The firehouse in Duluth's Lakeside section is a little like the communal well in a primitive village. All day long, cars pull up and people carrying an array of containers enter a door to obtain drinking water from one of three spouts hanging over a metal trough.
NEWARK, Feb. 19 Joseph A. Hoffman, State Commissioner of Labor and Industry, proposed today the tightening of regulations under which jobless people qualify for unemployment insurance in New Jersey.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed sharply higher yesterday in the heaviest trading in more than three years. Quotations in the over-thecounter market also advanced in accelerated trading.
A young woman sat in a darkened conference room in a Manhattan office building the other day, her attention fixed on a television set at the end of the room.
Frank Sullivan, the humorist, died yesterday in the Saratoga Hospital, Saratoga Springs, N.Y. He was 83 years old and lived alone at 135 Lincoln Avenue in Sartatoga Springs.
TOKYO, Feb. 19 Prime Minister Takeo Miki of Japan told his nation today that Japanese democracy would suffer a "fatal wound" if the Lockheed bribery scandal was left unsolved.

The Lion of Flanders looks like the tamest, friendliest jungle beast this side of Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey.

Three of the Democratic candidates for President Birch Bayh, Jimmy Carter and Henry M. Jackson filed delegate petitions in almost all of New York State's 39 districts yesterday.

KEENE, N.H., Feb. 19 President Ford accused Ronald Reagan of "pure political demgoguery" here tonight while his aides began trying to minimize the importance of the New Hampshire Presidential primary.

CAIRO, Feb. 19 (AP) An Egyptian Parliamentary committee has heard charges by one of its members that officials of Egyptair, the Government-owned airline, took commissions on the sale of aircraft from the Boeing Company, Cairo newspapers reported.

The Toyota Motor Company announced in Tokyo yesterday that it had received an inquiry from the Ford Motor Company for the purchase of five-speed transmissions for small passenger vehicles.

Supplies of distillate oil slipped in the latest week, according to statistics from the American Petroleum Institute, but analysts again asserted that there was no possibility of a shortage this winter.

The New York City Opera Company opened its spring season last night at the State Theater with a production of Wagner's "Die Meistersnger." At least, that was what it said on the program, though the English translation by John Gutman is used. Why not "Mastersingers," for consistency's sake?

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 Representatives Joseph P. Addabbo, Democrat of Queens, and Robert L. Leggett, Democrat of California, said today that they were being investigated by the Justice Department on charges of having accepted a bribe of under $10,000 last fall from the South Korean Government.

High school students in the state would not receive diplomas until they had demonstrated competency in four basic subjects under a proposal that the State Education Commissioner plans to submit to the Board of Regents.

Milton Cohen, vice president and general manager of Hertz System Inc., a licensee company that rents and leases cars and trucks in affiliation with the Hertz Corporation, died Wednesday in Vancouver, British Columbia. He was 58 years old and lived in Mount Vernon, N.Y.

In overturning a court-ordered racial quota designed to protect the jobs of black and Puerto Rican school principals, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit recently in effect proscribed racial discrimination even when it is intended to aid disadvantaged minorities. Ramsey Clark, the former Attorney General, said yesterday that there were "nearly 6,000 political prisoners in Uruguay."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 The Senate, by a vote of 97 to 0, approved legislation today to revise the nation's copyright law for the first time in 67 years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) Senator James L. Buckley withdrew today his opposition to temporarily continuing the Federal Election Commission. An aide said the move amounted to an invitation to the Justice Department to ask the Supreme Court to extend its deadline for reconstituting the panel.

Two masked men armed with pistols, who were believed to have watched as a shipment of money was brought to the Flushing branch of the Dry Dock Savings Bank, robbed the bank yesterday of $179,000, the police said.

An obscure and involved new accounting rule, affecting the way American-based multinational corporations translate their far-flung earnings and balance-sheet items into dollars, is expected to produce volatile swings in quarterly reported earnings by many of the nation's leading companies. But the change would not affect real operating earnings or cash flow.

The Stuttgart Piano Trio. which gave the first of two Mozart-Mendelssohn-Schubert concerts Thursday night at Carnegie Recital Hall (the second will be Thursday) as part of its third American tour, is capable of stirring, straightforward accounts of its music. The trouble is that the trio's playing was sometimes too stirring for its own good.

A demand was made in the House of Representatives yesterday that the Congressional press credentials of a television news reporter be revoked because he leaked a secret Congressional report to The Village Voice.

SANFORD, N.C., Feb. 15 Roy Stewart, the paving company owner who is also Mayor of this Southern industrial town of 11,500, worries about unemployment in his town, the high cost of living, inflation, crime and drugs. But mainly, like a great number of others in this sports-minded town, he worries about the fate of the American Legion baseball team, the state champions who were knocked out of national contention last season by a controversial loss.

MONTREAL, Feb. 20 Except for a Guy named Lapointe, the New York Rangers might have gained at least a point tonight at the Montreal Forum, where they haven't won a regular-season game since Feb. 22, 1972.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 20 (UPI) The Gulf Oil Corporation said today that it was trying to open negotiations with the Soviet-supported Angolan government at Luanda with the aim of resuming operation of its oil wells off the coast of the Angolan territory of Cabinda.
It was just about a perfect day yesterday for some do-ityourself pothole-filling on several quiet Brooklyn streets along with a lesson in participatory government.

CAIRO, Feb. 20 President Anwar el-Sadat will fly to Saudi Arabia with all the important members of his Cabinet tomorrow in an attempt to obtain urgently needed political and financial support from the Arab oil countries. Visits to Kuwait, Abu Dhabi, Bahrain and Qatar were added to the schedule at the last moment.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 20 Ronald Reagan, seeking to counter President Ford's contention that he is "too far to the right" to be elected Presi- dent, said today that he had twice been offered Cabinet posts in the Ford Administra- tion.

ABOARD THE ICEBREAKER URHO A weak winter sun hung somewhere over a horizon obliterated by the vast monotony of snow and white sky. The Finnish icebreaker Urho rumbled as the steel bow sliced cleanly at 15 knots through nearly two feet of snow-crusted ice on the frozen Gulf of Bothnia.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 20 Patricia Hearst's defense pro duced a man from jail today to tell a story that buttressed her contention that she had been coerced into helping with the robbery of the Hibernia Bank branch here for which she is on trial.

ZAMBOANGA, The Philippines, Feb. 20 (AP) Heavily armed men believed to be Moslem rebels ambushed a passenger bus, killed at least 21 persons and wounded several others in a town 87 miles north of Zamboanga, survivors said today.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 20 Richard M. Nixon set out today on his second trip to China, this time as a private citizen invited by the Chinese Government to revisit the scene of one of the brightest moments of his Presidency.
John Van Arsdale scaled a greased flagpole one day in 1783 and won himself a footnote in American history.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) A Federal judge today ordered the Boeing Company to turn over to the Securities and Exchange Commission any documents that might show foreign payoffs by the aircraft manufacturer.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 The Treasury sold today $2.5 billion of 21-month notes at an average return of 6.62 percent. The department received $4.8 billion of tenders for the notes, which will carry a coupon interest rate of 6 5/8 percent.
Prices paid by consumers in the New York-North Jersey region continued a moderate rise of seven-tenths of 1 percent last month, the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics announced yesterday.

Several hours of meetings yesterday failed to end a dispute between two types of dress-industry employers that has idled 20,000 to 30,000 workers since last Tuesday in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

Hamilton Bancshares Inc., a major regional holding company with banking interests in Tennessee and Georgia, filed for voluntary bankruptcy yesterday in Federal District Court in Chattanooga.

American Impressionism looked pretty strong at the Metropolitan Museum when the centenary of the movement was commemorated. WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (UPI) The House Interior Committee approved, 28 to 11, today a bill calling for Federal controls on strip mining, even though President Ford has twice vetoed similar measures.

MOSCOW, Feb. 24 Leonid T. Brezhnev asserted today that the Soviet Union would continue to seek accommodation with the West but would not back down from its ideological struggle, including the support of national liberation movements.

The 28 railroads operating west of the Mississippi have informed the Interstate Commerce Commission that they will not join Eastern and Southern railroads in the average freight rateinc rease of 4.7 percent that would take effect March 6.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 Vice President Rockefeller proposed to the nation's Governors today a five-point program to simplify and in some respects to enlarge greatly Federal financial aid to the states and their needy citizens.
Heartened by some favorable economic news, prices on the American Stock Exchange and on the over-the-counter market registered another advance yesterday in heavy trading.

PARIS, Feb. 24 Marcel Cavaille, French Secretary of State for Transport, today assailed as "discriminatory" and "anticonstitutional" a bill passed by the New York State Legislature that would in effect bar Concorde flights into Kennedy International Airport.

LISBON, Feb. 24 Portugal's military leadership expressed its concern today over "the increasing activity of certain antidemocratic and reactionary sectors," but insisted on holding national legislative elections on the original target date, April 25, to mark the second anniversary of the military coup against the former right-wing dictatorship.

HONG KONG, Feb. 24 For the first time since the current series of attacks on rightists in China intensified earlier this month, the Government newspaper today quoted Chairman Mao Tse-tung as personally expressing indignation at the rightists.

LONDON, Feb. 23 (Reuters) Britain's most controversial artistic exhibit, a pile of 120 fire bricks, was removed from public view at London's Tate Gallery today after a young man sprayed blue food coloring over it.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 Governor Carey's drive to transfer mental patients out of big institutions and into local communities a move he said would reduce the cost of mental-health care will not save much for the state this year or next, a panel of legislators was told today.

NASSAU, the Bahamas, Feb. 24 A yacht sank in the Miami-Nassau race just before dawn today and all of the crew were rescued by another yacht. The company employs about 40 persons here.

Kissinger had expressed support for Congressional efforts to allocate more than $500 million in additional aid to Israel this year, the Ford Administration has privately told key legislators that it prefers that no extra appropriations be made.

Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein's allegations of abuses in the adult homes in the state brought a promise by Senator Frank Moss, Democrat of Utah, yesterday that there would be a Federal inquiry, but a spokesman for owners of such homes described the Assemblyman as "a damned liar" who was fabricating the charges for political gain.

LONDON, Feb. 24 (AP) Prime Ministers Harold Wilson of Britain and Liam Cosgrave of Ireland will meet in London on March 5 to assess subsequent moves in the critical Northern Irish situation, the British Government announced today.

With traders keeping a weather eve on the Southwest and finding little hope for rain, wheat prices bounded up yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Early in the session there had been some reports of a possible one-tenth inch of rain in Oklahoma and Nebraska, but this was not enough to alleviate worries.

The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, the nation's No. 2 tire producer after the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, reversed its profit downtrend of the last year with an increase of 13.1 percent in earnings for the first fiscal quarter ended Jan. 31, according to results issued yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 24 A class-action shareholders' suit against the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation and a number of its present and former directors was filed in Federal District Court here today to enjoin the company from making any further "Payoffs or bribes to foreign governments" and public officials, and from providing any further "unlawful or undisclosed agents' commissions or other payments."

BLUE MOUND, Tex., Feb. 14 (AP) A machinist, his wife and two of their sons were shot to death in their home last night in a Fort, Worth suburb. The police said that another son came home later, found the alleged assailant still in the house and fatally wounded him.

According to unconfirmed reports from Los Angeles, Zubin Mehta will replace Pierre Boulez as conductor of the New York Philharmonic. Officials of the New York orchestra and of the Los Angeles Philharmonic, which Mr. Mehta has conducted since 1961, would neither deny nor confirm the rumor yesterday.

NEWARK, Feb. 24 Students at Seton Hall Law School may soon be working with the State Attorney General's office to develop a more effective method of regulating the state's solid-waste disposal industry.

Two Housing Authority detectives known as the Lone Ranger and Tonto arrested three alleged members of a six-man gang yesterday accused of having broken into and rifled the apartments of at least 50 people in four Brooklyn housing projects since early last month.

Andrew De Lillo, the head of two large Long Island companies making concrete pipes and girders, was indicted by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday on charges of embezzling nearly $1.5 million from a union pension and retirement benefit fund.

CULLOWHEE, N.C., Feb. 26 What governor of what state has overseen state expenditures that have grown by 356.9 percent while Federal Government outlays were going up only 176.7 percent? What governor in the same period has expanded his state's bureaucracy by 113.3 percent while the Federal bureaucracy was growing by only 17.1 percent? George Wallace of Alabama, that's who, in the period 1962 to 1974.

The credit markets, which have been heading toward lower interest rates for a week and shouldering a heavy volume of new issues with a great deal of success, ran into rough- er going yesterday.

Alfred G. Stoughton, who retired in 1969 as an information specialist for the United States Public Health Service, died Monday in Northampton, Mass., where he lived. He was 72 years old.

R.H. Macy Co. Inc., the city's largest retailer, and which operates 71 stores throughout the country, achieved the highest sales and earnings in its history in the quarter and half ended Jan. 31. Earnings rose 59 percent for the second quarter and 71.8 percent for the half-year.

GENEVA, Feb. 26 World trade, which grew in value about 4 percent last year but only because of price increases, should expand this year in volume as well as value, according to an international study.

If the Broadway run of "Pacific Overtures" presages an American infatuation with the traditional music of Japan, it will be necessary for the soloists of the Ensemble Nipponia to return for more engagements. The ensemble, performing at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night, offered a quick tour through some ancient Japanese styles that are unfamiliar in the West and a perspective on a movement combining traditional techniques with modern compositional structures.

Domestic Security The report by the General Accounting Office on domestic intelligence activities raises a most important issue as Congress contemplates the future of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. SAN FRANCISCO, Calif., Feb. 29 In an effort to explain how a kidnapping victim could take part in a bank robbery with her kidnappers, psychiatrists from around the country have been summoned to examine Patricia Hearst and report their findings to the jury in her bank robbery trial here.

Frank Grillo, the veteran Latin bandleader better known as Machito, celebrated a birthday Saturday evening at Town Half with the Collective Black Artists' big band. The meeting was an apt one, for during the 1940's Machito's was one of the first Latin groups to feature improvisations by jazzmen, among them Charlie Parker and Dizzy Gillespie.

Efforts to fashion a Democratic nonaggression pact collapsed yesterday, guaranteeing widespread challenges to the petitions that put candidates for delegates to the Presidential convention on the New York ballot.
TEL AVIV, Feb. 29 The Minister of Police, Shlomo Hillel, warned last night that Jews caught praying on the Temple Mount in Jerusalem would be arrested, in deference to Moslem sentiment.

A former engineer for the Mobil Oil Corporation who reportedly sold oil industry information to the Soviet Union and then became a double agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation died yesterday at his home in Southbury, Conn., of what the police said was a self-inflicted gunshot wound in the head.

JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 29 Rear-guard forces backing Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama failed at the state Democratic convention here today to unseat Aaron Henry, a black leader and longtime chairman of the loyalist faction, as cochairman of th newly united state Democratic party.

LANDOVER, Md., Feb. 29 (AP) The Washington Capitals, fresh from two morale-building ties with the Flyers and the Bruins, defeated the Chicago Black Hawks, 4-1, for their eighth National Hockey League triumph of the season, tying last year's victory total for the team.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Feb. 29 South Carolina Democrats gave Gov. George Wallace of Alabama a narrow victory over former Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia last night in a caucus race so close that most agreed it was a standoff.

Joseph Wittlin, Polish poet and novelist best known for "Salt of the Earth," which has been translated into 13 languages, died yesterday in the New York University Medical Center. He was 79 years old and lived at 5400 Fieldston Road, Riverdale, the Bronx.

DETROIT, March 5 Because of disappointing sales and high stocks, the American Motors Corporation said today it was cutting back Pacer production 25 percent more in a move that will indefinitely lay off another 1,000 workers at its Wisconsin plants.

For the first time in many years, the New York Democratic Presidential primary will be a crucial part of the process of winnowing out Presidential hopefuls a procedure that began in New Hampshire last week.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 5 If President Ford defeats Ronald Reagan in the Republican primary in Florida next Tuesday, it will be largely because the President seems to have a lock on the elderly vote, according to politicians, pollsters and other political analysts.

LANSING, Mich. March 5 (UPI) The State Labor Department concluded today that a spark from a welding torch set off a grain elevator explosion that killed five workers in Milawukee and cited the elevator operator for three willfu1 safety violations.

BETHEL, Me., March 5 Paced by Mike Meleski, a 145-pound freshman who learned to ski and race in the flat country of central Minnesota, the University of Wyoming today replaced Dartmouth as the leader in the National Collegiate Athletic Association championships.
DETROIT, March 6 (AP) From 1,500 to 2,000 city employees will be laid off April 1 to help cut Detroit's budget deficit, according to Deputy Mayor William Beckham Jr.
WASHINGTON, March 5 A House subcommittee supplied more evidence today that Congress would not raise the Social Security tax rate this year, as requested by President Ford.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (UPI) A Federal judge ruled today that the United States Postal Service had the right to shut down 600 rural post offices, provided it gave a 90-day notice and surveyed the effect on mail users.
Toppled from his Congressional power by alcoholism and public incidents with a striptease dancer, Representative Wilbur D. Mills called it quits yesterday and said he would not run for a 20th term.

WASHINGTON, March 5 The Democratic Party stretched its own rules today to make the Wisconsin Presidential primary election on April 6 a binding test that will select 68 national convention delegates as well as serving as a popularity contest for Presidential candidates.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 5 Patricia Hearst's chief defense lawyer, F. Lee Bailey, roared at a Government witness today, "Did you go and try to fix this case behind my back?"
TOKYO, March 5 Japanese police questioned today a Spanish-born Catholic priest, who is a naturalized Japanese citizen, about his alleged role as a channel for secret Lockheed funds coming into Japan.

As many as 1,000 Democrats will be running for the 205 district delegate posts to be filled in the April 6 primary. Sixty-nine additional delegates will be selected by the Democratic State Committee and apportioned to each candidate on the basis of the primary returns.

GOTEBORG, Sweden, March 5 (UPI) The only hope for a United States gold medal in the world figure skating championships lies with Dorothy Hamill, 19, years old, the Olympic's champion, who moved up to first place today after winning the women's short program with an almost perfect performance that earned her 87.36 points and 14.5 ordinals.

Stock prices closed out the first week of March with a modest gain yesterday in comparatively light turnover as the list appeared to extend its current consolidation period following the large advance registered in January and February.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (UPI) The Energy Research and Development Administration today announced plans for commercial production of a revolutionary new light bulb that consumes 70 percent less electricity and may not burn out for 10 years.

The International Business Machines Corporation's Office Products division introduced two models of its I.B.M. Series III copier-duplicator in Chicago yesterday. The new models are reportedly much faster than the previous line and feature an advanced document feed, completely automated duplexing and a rated speed of 4,500 copies an hour. Optional with both models, designated Model 10 and Model 20, are one of two collators, each with 20 bins.

ELIOT, Me., March 5 Rear Adm. Herbert B. Knowles, a retired Naval officer in both World Wars and a pioneer submarine commander, died Wednesday at the Maine Medical Center in Portland. He was 81 years old.

WASHINGTON, March 5 The problem of housing the nation's poor, always difficult but considerably worse during the recent recession, has produced none of the stirring calls for remedial action that might be expected in a Presidential election year.

UNIONDALE, L.I., March 5 Freeport defeated Lynbrook, 73-72, and Malverne overcame Westbury, 60-43, today at the Nassau Coliseum and gained the final of the Nassau County scholastic basketball tournament.
UNIONDALE, L.I., March 5 The dispirited Virginia Squires wrote another chapter in their nowhere season here tonight, losing to the New York Nets, 127-108.

WASHINGTON, March 5 The Comptroller of the Currency, James E. Smith, rejected late today a proposal that would permit a House subcommittee to supervise a detailed study of the effectiveness of his office in the examination of national banks.

From stem to stern, from top to bottom, from upper management to the checkout counter, the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company is being retrained. Stocks on the American Stock Exchange moved up a little yesterday, with the average closing at 103.65 up 0.47 from 103.18 Thursday, and showing a gain of 0.28 for the week. Trading volume of 4,060,000 shares compared with 3,931,000 the previous day.

MOSCOW, March 5 Born on Nov. 7, 1917, the very day the Bolsheviks took power, Dmitri Stepanovich Polyansky rose rapidly through the ranks of Communist politicians, hovered for a while at the fringes of substantive power, then began a long fall that culminated today in his ouster from the ruling Politburo. It was a career shaped and bruised by the roughand-tumble world of Soviet politics.
TUCSON, Ariz., March 5 As far as Dr. William L. Rathje and his 60 student volunteers at the University of Arizona are concerned, you are what you throw away.

A Police Department study of its own corruption situation has found that "the integrity level within this department is the highest than it has ever been" and that there is no evidence of organized graft.

Former Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind, responding to a state call for assistance, was reported yesterday to have found a way to neutralize the state's controversial stock transfer tax and to halt the flow of Wall Street brokers to New Jersey.

SEATTLE, March 5 (AP) The Boeing Company has made commission payments of $70 million in its overseas sales work during the last five years, the company acknowledged today. A spokesman said the payments to sales agents and subcontractors were all legal.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Mar. 5 Four European emigre organizations have sent to nonCommunist United Nations delegations lists of names and addresses of Soviet and Polish officials here they say are secret agents of the K.G.B., the Soviet intelligence and internal security agency. They asked for expulsion of the officials.

An explosion ripped through the walls of a water tower atop a 19-story psychiatric hospital on Wards Island yesterday morning, critically injuring a workman and sending chunks of brick and mortar the size of footballs through the ceiling of the infirmary. The debris narrowly missed 18 patients.

SAN FRANCISCO A littlenoted suit pending in United States District Court here is looked to by environmental lawyers as the possible key to resolving a virtual governmental deadlock over reducing airplane noise.

AMARILLO, Tex., March 5 (AP) Marvin Jones, former Chief Justice of the United States Court of Claims, former chairman of the House Agriculture Committee and an instrumental figure in much of the New Deal's farm legislation, died yesterday. He was 94 years old.

Ron Turcotte became the sixth jockey in New York major thoroughbred racing history to ride six winners in one day, accomplishing the feat yesterday at Aqueduct. Among his winners was Samuel Lehrman's Campaign Donation, who won the $20,000 feature by two lengths.

COPENHAGEN Birgitte Jensen was born on June 26, 1972, but spent only three days with her parents. A social worker said that the infant's parents seemed unable to care for her, so the child was placed in an institution.

BONN, March 5 The West German Government is worried about what Chancellor Helmut Schmidt sees as a leadership crisis in Washington, according to his close aides. Kissinger's agreement to consult Brazil on all major events of international significance should be taken seriously, be cause Brazil is South America's dominant power and will wield increasing influence on the African side of the South Atlantic basin. A United States policy that recognizes regional preeminence is realistic and serves our national interest by preserving a friendship that is as utilitarian as it is mutually attractive.

The New York State United Teachers voted yesterday to disaffiliate from the National Education Association, a move that is certain to lead to the withdrawal of some N.E.A. loyalists from the 211,000-member state union. The vote was 157,400 to 37,729.

About to miss out on the National Hockey League playoffs for the first time in 10 years, the New York Rangers put on their happy faces last night at the Plaza.

With his delegate candidates ruled off the ballot in 13 Congressional districts and facing the same fate in 11 other districts, Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama is in danger of being eliminated as a factor in the April 6 New York Democratic Presidential primary.

LONDON, March 8-The British are observing the bicentennial of the publication of Adam Smith's, "The Wealth of Nations" in what is probably characteristic British fashion--with debates, deliberations and an essay contest but little apparent hoopla.
Edith Altschul Lehman, widow of former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman of New York and, in her own right, a leading philanthropist, died early yesterday. She was 86 Years old.
Clifford W. Michel, an investment banker, died Monday at his home at 35 East 76th Street. He was 64 years old.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the over-thecounter market finished higher yesterday in moderate trading.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 8-Two dozen of the highest priced stars in baseball held an extraordinary meeting on the infield grass at Eckerd College here today and voted to send a delegation to help unlock the stalemate that has closed the spring training camps.

WASHINGTON, March 8 Despite stepped-up activity, Congress appears unlikely to reach agreement on new changes in the Federal campaign law in time to meet the second deadline imposed by the Supreme Court.

An offering of 2 million common shares of the Toledo Edison Company, at $23 a share, was made yesterday by underwriters headed by the First Boston Corporation and Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith Inc.
CAIRO, March 8 Egypt accused Libya today of having sent seven soldiers in civilian clothes to Cairo to kidnap two dissident Libyan politicians and commit other acts of violence.

WASHINGTON, March 8 Attorney General Edward H. Levi will impose guidelines on the Federal Bureau of Investigation in three areas in an effort to halt abuses disclosed in 18 months of Congressional inquiry, Capitol Hill and Administration sources said today.
ELMIRA, N.Y. March 8 (AP) John J. Devlin, said to be the country's oldest police officer when he retired in April 1974, died here yesterday. He was 90 years old.

With his delegate candidates ruled off the ballot in 13 Congressional districts and facing the same fate In 11 other districts, Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama is in danger of being eliminated as a factor in the April 6 New York Democratic Presidential primary.

Baroness Pauline de Rothschild, American-born wife of Baron Philippe de Rothschild, owner of Chateau Mouton-Rothschild, the famous French wine property, died yesterday of a heart attack at Santa Barbara, Calif. She was 67 years old.

WASHINGTON, March 8 A mysterious company with no visible office or directors, calling itself Malpractice Research Inc., is offering a mail-order "review" of "potential malpractice cases" by anonymous physicians for an $80 fee, of which half must be paid in advance.
A smoky fire that burned out of control for more than 25 hours on an abandoned Hudson River pier at the foot of West 11th Slreet was being investigated yesterday as a possible case of arson.

WASHINGTON, March 8 In an unusual action that drew the objection of the Chief Justice, the Supreme Court announced today its view of a major and previously unresolved voting rights issue in a footnote to an opinion on another, less controversial, voting rights issue.

NEWARK, March 8-Officials of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey expected commuter rail lines today to meet much of the demand for alternative service to New York in the event of a strike against the Transport of New Jersey Bus Company.
Raymond G. Leddy, a retired foreign Service officer who specialized in Latin American affairs, died Friday on vacation in Punta Gorda, Fla. He was 63 years old and lived in Carlisle, Pa.
A small bomb exploded with a reverberating roar last night outside a Fifth Avenue building housing the Soviet and Czechoslovak national airlines.
NEW DELHI, March 8 The Indian Parliament resumed today for a two-month session, that is expected to be devoted largely to economic matters.
BOMBAY, India, March 8 In a small, sunny parlor in a middle-class suburb of Bombay, two dozen old men gather for an hour or so at the end of every day to discuss their common problems.
MIAMI, March 8 On radio station WMBM, the heavy beat of soul music was occasionally followed by a political commercial from Senator Henry M. Jackson.
The alertness of a four-yearold German shepherd dog has led to the arrest of five men on charges of smuggling more than $3 million worth of hashish into the United States from Bombay, India.
Dale Fabyan, an assistant vice president with the First Boston Corporation died early Monday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 34 years old and lived at 170 East 79th Street.

David M. Church, the first full-time paid chief executive of the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel, died yesterday in North Penn Hospital in Lansdale, Pa. He was 82 years old and lived in Philadelphia.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 8 Tony Darden posted a national record of 30.3 seconds for the 300-yard dash; Bill Hartley cleared 15 feet 10 inches in the pole vault for an East Coast mark, and Alberto Salazar smashed the two-mile meet record tonight at the Eastern States schoolboy indoor track and field championships in Jadwin Gym.
ALBANY, March 8 March had figured to be a month of high drama in Albany, the culmination of the yearlong fiscal crisis and the ultimate test of the state's solvency.

Hollace Shaw, who sang her way to fame in the 1930's and 40's as a soloist with the CBS radio network here, died in Los Angeles last Tuesday. She was 62 years old and lived in Fall River Mills, Calif.

The United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission is reported to have accepted jurisdiction in a complaint by a woman who was ordained to the Episcopal priesthood but denied employment as a priest by her Bishop.

The season's first "Der Rosenkavalier," last night at the Metropolitan Opera, had several newcomers in key roles, and one of those was a debut. Tatiana Troyanos, the American mezzo-soprano who was active at the New York City Opera and since then has gone on to some of the leading international houses, was the Octavian.

DANIELSON, Conn. Unemployment is not a passing phenomenon in Windham County. The people who live on the gentle slopes in the rustic northeastern corner of Connecticut or alongside the aging Red-brick mills on the winding Quinebaug River have endured hard times for 30 years.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (UPI) Board members of the American Foreign Service Association voted today to censure the association's president for criticizing some Foreign Service officers before a Senate committee.
The Quaker State Oil Refining Corporation of Oil City, Pa., and the Valley Camp Coal Company of Cleveland, will merge through an exchange of stock, it was announced yester- day.

Simon Wiesenthal, who has spent most of his life pursuing Nazi war criminals and who played a prominent role in the discovery of Adolf Eichmann in Argentina, said last night that "maybe in a few months we'll have something" on 62 suspected war criminals who are believed to be in the United States.

WASHINGTON, March 8 The State Department said today that it would discipline the official who provided secret material on Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger's conversations with Middle East leaders that was included in an article just published.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 8 Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama toured the length of the Florida peninsula by plane today in a last-minute push for every possible vote in tomorrow's Democratic Presidential primary.

EAST CAMDEN, Ark., March 8 (AP)-A series of explosions went off at a military materials plant at noon today, leaving three employees dead and 20 injured, the plant manager said, touched off the explosions.
MOSCOW, March 8 (AP) A World Team Tennis squad from America barely led a Soviet team after the first day of competition today.

The conviction of Jack L. Chestnut, the former campaign manager for Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, on charges that he accepted an illegal corporate campaign contribution of $12,000 in 1970 was upheld yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, according to United Press International.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 8 Israel has restated to the United Nations its determination to curb religious demonstrations by Jews at Jerusalem's Temple Mount, a shrine area sacred to both the Jewish and Moslem faiths.

Protesting parents who were careful not to drop cigarette ashes on the floor or cause much disturbance yesterday occupied offices at a public school on the West Side in a vain effort to stop the Board of Education from reducing the instructional time of pupils.

WASHINGTON, March 8 Recent fossil discoveries in East Africa have yielded strong evidence that the form of early man that had evolved by 3.75 million years ago was anatomically much more like modern man than had been supposed.

LONDON, March 8 (Reuters) Ireland's premier peer, the seventh Duke of Leinster, who might have been one of Britain's wealthiest men, died penniless here tonight in a tiny two-room apartment. He was 83 Years old.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 8 (AP) Secretary General Kurt Waldheim has ordered Sean MacBride, the United Nations Commissioner for Namibia, or South-West Africa, to coordinate future statements with headquarters, a United Nations spokesman said today.

SEOUL, South Korea, March 8-President Park Chung Hee of South Korea appeared today to have intensified a crackdown on his political critics with the arrest of his last presidential opponent and a onetime foreign minister.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 8 An expert witness for the pros- ecution testified today that in his opinion Patricia Hearst voluntarily joined her revolutionary captors within four weeks of her kidnapping and then took part willingly in the bank robbery for which she is on trial.

MADRID, March 8 An 18year-old man was killed by Civil Guards near Bilbao today as hundreds of thousands of Basques struck and demonstrated in protest against the death of four persons at the hands of the police in Vitoria last week.

WASHINGTON, March 8 Attorney General Edward H. Levi will impose guidelines on the Federal Bureau of Investigation in three areas in an effort to halt abuses disclosed in 18 months of Congressional inquiry, Capitol Hill and Administration sources said today.

A parade of speakers at a public hearing of the Board of Higher Education yesterday attacked a plan to restructure the City University, calling it morally bankrupt, shortsighted and a surrender to budget-conscious bureaucrats.

The Federal Power Commission held a hearing here yesterday on a controversial proposal by the nation's electric and natural gas companies that would allow them to require customers to pay the cost of building power plants years before they begin to provide energy.
PEKING, March 8 (Reuters) Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiao-ping, already under fire for being a "capitalist roader," was today accused by the women of Peking of being a male chauvinist.

NEW HAVEN, March 7 If atmosphere constituted plays there would be a play in every Dublin barroom and probably in every Irish dance hall. Unfortunately plays are more than atmosphere they need to be a translation of life, a view of life, not simply an evocative recording of life.
POTOMAC, Md., March 8 (UPI) The five bodies found in a shallow North Carolina grave last week were the mother, wife and three sons of a missing State Department official, authorities said today.

Mayor Beame sat on one side of the aisle; the actor George C. Scott sat across from him on the other. Both wer ewaiting to go on. Art and politics and a hefty amount of money were joined last night in celebrating the 25th anniversary of the Circle in the Square Theatre.
ORLANDO, Fla., March 8 They finally completed the Florida Citrus open golf tournament this morning as Hale Irwin beat Kermit Zarley by a stroke on the sixth hole of a sudden-death playoff.

The National Transportation Safety Board put forward yesterday a broad set of recommendations to reduce the danger of aircraft accidents caused on take off when jet engines are crippled by ingesting birds.

KANSAS CITY (AP) Joe Pace's game-high 29 points and 14 rebounds today enabled ninth-seeded Coppin State to post a 78-55 victory over Dowling College of Oakdale, L.I., in a first-round game at the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics basketball tournament.

Governor Carey yesterday appointed Stephen Berger, the State Commissioner of Social Services, to replace Herbert Elish as the chief administrator of the Emergency Financial Control Board, the state panel overseeing the city's fiscal reform.

BOSTON, March 8 (UPI) A 54-year-old man has been arrested and charged with sending more than 100 letters threatening the lives of Boston area doctors because he blamed the medical profession for the death of his father.
LISBON, March 8 (Reuters) Radical left-wing workers who seized the Socialist newspaper Republica last May handed the keys back to its owners today, the former editor, Raul Rego, said.
Interest rates declined slightly yesterday in the wake of the Federal Reserve injection of reserves into the banking system last Friday only shortly after it had indicated it would ...

WASHINGTON, March 8 Justice John Paul Stevens, in his first public dissents since joining the Supreme Court last December, showed today that he is willing to take the liberal position as well as the conservative.

The nation's first woman major general, Jeanne M. Holm, was appointed by President Ford yesterday to be his special assistant for women's affairs. Miss Holm, aged 54, retired from the Air Force last June as director of its personnel council. From 1965 to 1972 she was director of women in the Air Force.
In Illinois, where an important Republican primary will be held one week from today, President Ford has been energetically trying to rebuild his support among farmers.

The Western Union Corporation announced yesterday that it planned to pass through to its users as of March 20 a 5-cent increase in payments to the United States Postal Service for delivery of each Mailgram message. The compa- ny also said that it would reduce from 30 to 10 cents the handling fee for business reply Mailgram service with the new price effective immediately for 60 days.
Two revolutions were begun in 1776.

Rain of three-quarters to an inch over wheat areas of central and western Oklahoma surprised grain traders yesterday at the Chicago Board of Trade. The panhandle region of Texas and parts of Kansas also received rain, described as "sparse" and no more than two-tenths of an inch.
"Well, I guess I'm officially on strike," said George Bronee, the bus driver, as he Steered the No. 61 to Hoboken down the ramp of the Port Authority bus terminal shortly after midnight.

ALVOCO DAS VARZEAS, Portugal, March 8 "We defeated a Communist move to set up a dictatorship and we're going to fight just as hard to prevent a return of the fascists," the Socialist leader, Mario Soares, told a crowd of several hundred farmers in this modest village 200 miles northeast of Lisbon.

TEANECK, N.J., March 8 Joseph P. Merlino, the Democratic majority leader of the State Senate, disclosed tonight that he would conduct a legislative investigation into alleged racial steering in the suburban housing market in Bergen County.

Margaret C. Baird, the principal of Jefferson High School in the East New York section of Brooklyn, says she tries to hide her fear as she walks the corridors of her school. And she seldom walks alone.

HARTFORD, March 8 Connecticut was given a strong measure of reassurance today when Standard Poor's rating service decided to retain the state's AA bond rating.

LOS ANGELES, March 8 In the first confrontation between the petroleum industry and a state over conditions of new offshore oil development, a major oil company vowed last week to do its initial processing at sea rather than meet state requirements for onshore operations.

It would be hard for a violinist to select a braver program when Yuval Waldman chose for his recital at Carnegie Recital Hall on Sunday night: three works, all unaccompanied and all packed with technical and interpretative problems calling for the highest level of virtuosic playing.
ATLANTA, March 8 The head of the American Bankers Association called today for greater disclosure by the nation's banks to stem what he called "an erosion of confidence" in the banking system.

Arthur Ashe, fresh from his victories in the World Cup, was in town yesterday to pick up an award as the Martini Rossi tennis player of the year. The award included a check for $7,500. Ashe indicated he had patched up his differences with Jimmy Connors, whom he called "a very charming guy" and "the biggest male attraction in tennis."

SEATTLE, March 8 (AP) The Internal Revenue Service is conducting an investigation of Boeing Company overseas commission payments as part of a routine audit of company records, the aerospace concern said today.

When David Bronstein offered me a draw after 25 moves of our game in the Alekhine Memorial Tournament in Moscow in 1971, I was quite willing to accept. The position had become a tortuous tangle of backward pawns and weak squares on both sides and, if anyone had the advantage, it was a mystery to both of us.
TRENTON, March 8 A bill to put a 5 percent ceiling on increases in state spending for general operations was approved today by the Assembly Taxation Committee.

Howard R. Hughes, the reclusive billionaire, did it again yesterday. He failed to appear before the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington to give a deposition in connection with the Government agency's suit against him, several of his companies and some of his associates.
Edward J. Winters, a retired Investment broker, died Saturday in Frederiksted, St. Croix, Virgin Islands. He was 82 years old.

The union representing 2,000 clerks and cashiers at Offtrack Betting Corporation offices throughout the city threatened a strike for 7:30 A.M. tomorrow unless their salaries and those of branch managers were deferred on an equal basis.

The city called yesterday upon the head of a huge real-estate organization to take trespass action against the occupants of Luxor Baths, who are allegedly converting the nine-story building in the Times Square area into one of the most lavish "massage" and prostitution establishments in the nation.

ALBANY, March 8 The Senate approved and sent to the Assembly today a bill that would allow an estimated total of 200,000 people in New York City, whose eligibility to vote would ordinarily would have lapsed, to vote in two primaries and one election this year.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 8 (AP) A Federal court judge today postponed the start of the Stephen Soliah bank robbery trial for one day after refusing to bar the press and the public from the questioning of prospective jurors.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 8 An expert witness for the prosecution testified today that in his opinion Patricia Hearst voluntarily joined her revolutionary captors within four weeks of her kidnapping and then took part willingly in the bank robbery for which she is on trial.
ROME, March 8 Pope Paul VI today entered a yearly period of spiritual retreat amid growing speculation on the state of his health.
At least one of the three trustees of The Harvard Lampoon is not pleased with the editorial direction of The National Lampoon.
Valerie Louthan has come a long way since she began updating Scottish cashmere styling four years ago. Knickers are a long way.

LONDON, March 8 (UPI) Nigeria said today that it had demanded the recall of Britain's diplomatic representative because he presented a bill for damage to his office before the mourning period had ended for Nigeria's slain head of state.

In an effort to spur the longdelayed Battery Park City, New York City's construction unions announced yesterday that they had promised labor peace to the builders of the $1.5 billion development to be built on landfill in the Hudson River.

TRENTON, March 8 (AP)-Six of New Jersey's top Republican office holders and the most recent gubernatorial candidate got on President Ford's bandwagon today.
NAIROBI, Kenya, March 8 (AP) President Idi Amin of Uganda has urged women pilots of the Uganda Air Force to exercise self-control, after disclosure that two of the seven being trained are pregnant.

Scandals have disfigured this nation's grain sales to the Soviet Union and other foreign nations. Shipments have included defective and contaminated grain. When cargo ships were hard to get, dirty, ill-maintained vessels have been pressed into service.
PENSACOLA, Fla., March 8 -When asked for his opinion of the recent New Hampshire primary, Gov. Reubin Askew of Florida said it was a case of Jimmy Carter "shaking 50,000 hands to get 25,000 votes."

The RCA Corporation disclosed yesterday that it had signed a contract with its former chairman and chief executive officer, Robert W. Sarnoff, for him to "furnish consultation and advice to RCA and the National Broadcasting Company on matters with respect to which he has special competence."

Behind the scenes at the American Museum of Natural History, a group of volunteers with specialized skills work diligently to provide what the museum believes are invaluable contributions. Without them, museum officials say, the institution would lose some of its richness.

BOMBAY In its 29 years of independence, India has increased its population more than the United States has in all the 200 years of its history. To its 628 million people it is currently adding some 13 million annually, which is equivalent to absorbing an Australia a year.

BACOLOD, the Philippines, March 8 (AP) School gymnasiums, swimming pools and churches in this "sugar bowl" of the Philippines have been turned into emergency sugar storehouses in what trade sources say is a gamble by the Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos to force up the sagging world sugar price.
BUENOS AIRES, March 8 Industrial workers went on strike today in the northern city of Cordoba against the Peronist Government's new economic austerity program, which freezes wages for 180 days.

The Arabian American Oil Company declined to say yesterday whether a definite agreement on the take-over of Aramco by the Saudi Government would be announced following a meeting between the Aramco partners being held in Panama City, Fla.
Rabbi Abraham J. Appleman of the Nathan Straus Jewish Center in the Bronx died Friday of a heart attack at his home, 3435 Gates Place the Bronx. He was 62 years old.

Pressures to broaden the scope of education in the nation's medical schools can lead to serious problems for the future of these institutions, two medical experts said here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 8 Leaders of American Jewish organizations told President Ford in a telegram today that they were "most strenuously opposed" to the Administration's plan to lift the military embargo against Egypt beginning with the sale of six C-130 military transports.

Publicker Distillers Products didn't take long to find a new agency to replace the J. Walter Thompson Company for its Inver House Scotch. JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 8 Ronald Reagan departed from Florida today on the eve of the vital primary here to go on to campaign in Illinois, and the candidate was uncharacteristically downbeat on his chances to defeat President Ford in either state.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (UPI) Congress should look into whether auto manufacturers and dealers are inflating prices on replacement parts to make up for lost sales and to put pressure on customers to buy new cars, a Federal consumer official said today.

Some taxpayers who exchanged New York City notes for 8 percent bonds of the Municipal Assistance Corporation last year are annoyed because the Internal Revenue Service has not offered guidance on the question of tax losses involved in the swap.

A 50-year-old former housing inspector collapsed in State Supreme Court yesterday as a jury acquitted him of accepting $30 in payoffs from an undercover police sergeant to overlook building violations in a midtown masage parlor.
WASHINGTON, March 8 (UPI) Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, announced today that he had accepted $15,000 to settle a lawsuit he filed against the makers of Dannon Yogurt and its advertising agency.
Tom (The Bomb) Bethea put on a strong finish to take a split decision over Billy (Dynamite) Douglas last night in their 10-round light- heavyweight fight at Madison Square Garden.

CBS-TV's "American Parade" series, keyed to the Bicentennial, reaches its most artistically successful level tonight, at 10 o'clock, with "Song of Myself," an impressionistic, rather sketchy but generally effective portrait of Walt Whitman. Jan Hartman's quite admirable script focuses on Whitman as poet, son, brother, wanderer, eccentric and, with unusual but unsensational candor, homosexual.

OTTAWA, March 8 (AP) Canada will decide by the end of this month whether to go ahead with a $1 billion purchase of 18 long-range patrol airplanes from the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation Supply Minister Jean-Pierre Goyer said today.

But despite a major reputation through records and several American tours, this was the Hungarian string quartet's first important New York date.

Nancy Weingarten Faber, author of "The Retarded Child" and other books, died Monday at her home here. She was 66 years old and also lived in Westport, Conn.

SEOUL, South Korea, Wednesday, March 10 (AP) The South Korean Government today released four prominent opposition figures who had been detained in connection with the reading of a manifesto demanding the restoration of fill democracy.

Vice President Rockefeller warned last night that "centrally controlled, Marxist," totalitarian power is gaining ground, not losing it, supported by subversion, sabotage and so-called wars of liberation."

Jack Dreyfus Jr., chairman of the board of the New York Racing Association, will recommend to the trustees today an innovation so up-to-date, functional and altogether desirable that George D. Widener will still he whirling in his grave on Belmont Stakes Day. It is an electronic device, similar to a monster television screen, that will enable racing fans to see the races they attend.

An active Government-buying program could become a powerful instrument for dealing with members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries one that must be used with great subtlety if it is not to backfire. Government orders at market prices would undermine the policy of trying to bring oil prices down; yet too heavy-handed an attempt to undercut the cartel prices might force greater cohesion and suspicion in OPEC.
Ten out of 19 body and baby powders tested at Mount Sinai Hospital here were contaminated with asbestos fibers capable of causing a rare form of chest and abdominal cancer, researchers have reported.

The first of a series of final regulations for the implementation of a law that gives parents and students the right to inspect school records has been published by the Federal Government. But the issue of whether some educational institutions may be exempt from the law has been left unclarified.

LONDON, March 9 Transmission of news in the early 19th century was a leisurely business. London's Morning Chronicle scored a journalistic coup by announcing the victory at Waterloo four days after the battle. News of Napoleon's death six years later took seven weeks to reach Britain.
A net deposit gain of $373 million during February was reported yesterday by the Savings Bank Association of New York state for its 118 members.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (Reuters)-The House of Representatives, in an emotional outburst against foreign travel by Congressmen, refused today to send a delegation to Britain to pick up a copy of Magna Carta for display here in the Bicentennial year.
SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., March 9 (AP) Student interest in vegetarianism has led to the establishment of a vegetarian lunch center at Mount Holyoke College.

Two men who were arrested Monday night were said by the police yesterday to have been responsible for 23 bank holdups in Queens, Nassau and Suffolk Counties in the last 10 months that netted them $750,000 to $1 million.

BRUSSELS, March 9 The Common Market Commission today predicted a rise of 3 percent to 3.5 percent in the gross national product of the nine-nation group in 1976 but cautioned that the strength of the recovery was still fragile.

The New York delegate slates that were cast adrift when Senator Birch Bayh suspended his Presidential campaign could shift either to Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota or Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona, a spokesman said yesterday.

BURBANK, Calif., March 9 (UPI) The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation announced today that it could not meet the necessary legal requirements in the time required and was asking for an extension of the May 15 deadline for the latest phase of its refinancing plan.

An independent audit of the city's $35-million antipoverty program has called into question up to $3.8 million of expenditures by Bedford-Stuyvesant Youth-in-Action, one of the most active community corporations in the program, and has resulted in an investigation by a Federal grand jury.

It is not unusual to find some contemporary handcrafted pieces tucked away in a department store gallery, amid the lithographs and marked-down Eskimo sculpture. But it is unusual, at least in this part of the country, to discover a first-rate show in a highly visible, if cramped, setting on the main floor of a store.

ROCK ISLAND, Ill., March 9 Ronald Reagan expressed "delight tonight in the unofficial returns from the Florida primary and said that he would remain in the race for the Republican nomination for President until he could begin winning contests in the primary states of the South and West.
BALTIMORE, March 9 (AP) Federal officials have been ordered to halt moves to cut off $88 million in aid to Maryland's colleges and universities and city schools in Baltimore.

A few days before CBS News suspended its correspondent Daniel Shorr for giving the House Intelligence Committee's secret report on the Central Intelligence Agency to The Village Voice for publication, top officials of CBS News received a telegram from the affiliates executive committee of CBS Radio asking that Mr. Schorr be taken off the air.
A Manhattan sergeant, a 30year veteran of the police force, was arrested yesterday on an indictment charging him with accepting bribes to protect a loan-sharking and gambling operation in Chinatown.

DALLAS, March 10 A moderate desegregation plan calling for the busing of 20,000 students and the division of the city into five subdistricts to achieve racial integration in Dallas schools was ordered by a Federal court here today.
The latest nationwide Gallup Poll shows that President Ford's job performance rating has increased to 50 percent approval, 11 points higher than his rating last December.
Ilie Nastase, the on-again, off-again scourage of tennis, is off again.

The New York Times/CBS News poll is based on interviews with a random sampling of Florida voters as they left the voting places Tuesday. Fifteen voting precincts throughout the state were selected and, within each precinct, each voter had an equal chance of being interviewed.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (UPI) The director of the National Cancer Institute told the Food and Drug Administration today that it was impossible to say for sure whether the artificial sweetener cyclamate was capable of causing human cancer.

To the surprise and bewilderment of Federal and city housing officials, only 4,600 New York City families have applied for a new rent subsidy program for which it is estimated that as many as one million households here are eligible.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 10 The 100th anniversary of the first telephone call between Alexander Graham Bell and Thomas A. Watson was celebrated here today by a great deal of talking. The talk focused less on the telephone's pervasiveness in the past than on the likelihood of an even more total penetration of daily life in the future.
TEXARKANA, Tex., March 10 (AP)-More than 1,000 mourners, led by scores of Congressmen, attended today the funeral of Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas.
The Horn Hardart Company, which has been turning its cafeterias into Burger King fast food operations, announced yesterday that it had signed an exclusive franchise agreement

TEHERAN, Iran, March 10 The Iranian Government, cutting back on expenditures, has piled up $2 billion in surplus revenues during the 10 months that ended with January, wellplaced members of the Teheran business community have reported.

LYNDHURST, March 10 The Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission accepted a proposal today for the construction of a $28.4 million system for producing fuel, ferrous metals and clean landfill for more than half of the garbage being poured into the commission's waste-disposal dumps.

ST. LOUIS, March 10 (AP) Marvin Barnes blocked seven shots and scored 23 points as he led the Spirits of St. Louis to a 99-95 victory over New York despite Julius Erving's 39-point performance for the Nets in an American Basketball Association game tonight.

Rival plans for a four-year program of public higher education on Staten Island have been put forward by the presidents of the two City University units there, at least one of whom would presumably have to lose his post.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland Gudmundur Kjaernested is a folk hero among the 220,000 inhabitants of this remote island republic of glaciers, volcanoes and earthquakes. He is captain of the Tyr, the biggest of the Icelandic Coast Guard's six patrol vessels. Armed with a 57-millimeter gun that he said was made in 1895, and "a little pistol for boarding parties," Captain Kjaernested is fighting the British, and he is widely thought here to be winning.

TRENTON, March 10 Representatives of the British and French governments buttonholed startled legislators today in the halls of the State House and on the Assembly floor for support of flights to the United States by the Concorde supersonic jet transport.
Gasoline stocks were reduced and heating oil reserves climbed in the latest week, according to figures issued yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

ROME, March 10 (AP) Senator Attilio Piccioni, a co-founder of the Christian Democratic Party and a member of the Italian Cabinet before his political career was eclipsed when his son was involved in a sex and death scandal that rocked Italy in the 1950's, died here today. He was 83 years old.

While the Dow Jones industrial average's flirtation with the 1,000 mark captures the headlines, a more esoteric number the little-known Federal funds rate is being increasingly scrutinized by Wall Street professionals as the key to the behavior of the securities markets.
